vectors.technique_name: Spearphishing Link (Consent Phishing for Slack OAuth Apps)

method_steps.description: Register a Slack app under the attacker’s control, define a manifest requesting high‑value scopes (for example, read channel history, files, user info, or admin.* scopes for enterprise apps), and enable unlisted distribution to obtain OAuth install URLs.
related_capabilities: OAuth-based authentication and tokens for apps
App distribution and Slack Marketplace listing
Developer tools: Slack CLI, Bolt frameworks, SDKs, and sandboxes
Web API for core Slack operations
related_interfaces: OAuth 2.0 authorization and token endpoints – installing with OAuth
Scopes and permissions reference
App management dashboard / distribution settings UI
Slack CLI commands for app creation and deployment
related_data: app manifest (requested scopes, events, surfaces)
client_id and client_secret
redirect URIs
OAuth install URL
prospective access tokens (bot/user/app)
method_steps.notes: The app can be undistributed or unlisted, so it does not need to pass Marketplace review to be installable via a direct OAuth URL.

method_steps.description: Craft a convincing spearphishing message that embeds the legitimate Slack OAuth install URL, targeting users who can install apps (ideally workspace or org admins). Deliver it via corporate email or, if already in limited contact, via Slack Connect or DMs.
related_interfaces: Slack email-style invitations or corporate email (out of scope but used for delivery)
Slack Connect channel/DM UI for in‑Slack lures
Messages surface in Slack clients
related_data: email or Slack identifiers of target admins/users
phishing email content including the OAuth link
method_steps.notes: Real‑world consent‑phishing campaigns (e.g., Pawn Storm against OAuth apps) use legitimate‑looking SaaS consent URLs to avoid attachment scanning and to normalize the flow.

method_steps.description: When the victim clicks the OAuth URL, Slack presents a legitimate consent page after enforcing SSO and MFA as configured. The page lists the attacker‑controlled app and requested scopes; the victim clicks “Allow” (or submits an install request that an admin later approves).
related_capabilities: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
OAuth-based authentication and tokens for apps
related_interfaces: Slack login/SSO flow (SAML SSO, MFA)
OAuth consent screen for app installation
Admin app approval UI / admin app approval APIs
related_data: SAML assertions and MFA challenges (handled by the IdP)
authorization code issued by Slack OAuth endpoint
app installation record for the workspace/org
method_steps.notes: Environment constraints (MFA Required, SSO-Only Authentication, IP Allowlisting) are satisfied by the legitimate user’s browser session and do not materially hinder this flow.

method_steps.description: On successful consent (and any required admin approval), Slack’s OAuth token endpoint exchanges the authorization code for access token(s) and possibly refresh or rotation information, which are delivered to the attacker’s redirect URI under their control.
related_capabilities: OAuth-based authentication and tokens for apps
Web API for core Slack operations
related_interfaces: OAuth token endpoint
App backend or redirect handler endpoint controlled by the attacker
related_data: bot access token and/or user token
granted scope list
workspace_id, user_id returned by auth.test or equivalent verification call
method_steps.notes: From the Slack perspective, this is an ordinary app install; the novelty is only that the consent was socially engineered.

method_steps.description: Use the stolen OAuth token to make initial Web API calls (for example, auth.test, conversations.list, conversations.history, files.list) to enumerate accessible workspaces, channels, users, and recent content within the scope granted to the app.
related_capabilities: Web API for core Slack operations
related_interfaces: Web API endpoints such as auth.test, conversations.list, conversations.history, users.info, files.list
Events API subscription/delivery endpoints (if the app also subscribed to events)
related_data: workspace_id and team metadata
channel_id and membership lists
message_ts and message bodies in accessible channels/DMs
file_id and file metadata and content where files:read is granted
method_steps.notes: This is the point at which initial access to the victim’s Slack tenant is achieved: the attacker now has a standing, token‑based foothold.

capabilities_used: OAuth-based authentication and tokens for apps
App distribution and Slack Marketplace listing
Developer tools: Slack CLI, Bolt frameworks, SDKs, and sandboxes
Web API for core Slack operations
Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
interfaces_used: Admin app approval UI and app-approval APIs
data_accessed: OAuth access tokens (bot/user/app) for the victim workspace
Granted scope list for the installed app
Workspace and team identifiers (workspace_id, team_id)
Channel lists and metadata (channel_id, names, membership) the token can see
Message history and files in in‑scope channels/DMs
Potentially admin data (users, channels, approvals) if admin scopes are granted
preconditions_required: Attacker can register a Slack app and host a reachable OAuth redirect endpoint.
Target users have active Slack accounts in the victim workspace and can authenticate via SSO and MFA.
Org app‑governance policies permit the targeted users (or their admins) to install or request installation of new apps, at least from unlisted distribution.
Phishing or spearphishing infrastructure to deliver convincing emails or messages with the Slack OAuth URL to specific users/admins.
If IP Allowlisting is enforced, the victim user accesses Slack from an allowlisted IP when clicking the consent link.
constraints_encountered: MFA Required – user must complete MFA to access Slack/consent page; mitigated by relying on the legitimate user to do so.
SSO-Only Authentication – users authenticate via IdP; the phishing flow leverages the normal SSO flow rather than bypassing it.
IP Allowlisting – consent must be completed from an allowlisted IP; attacker relies on the victim’s own network or VPN.
Admin Approval Required (for app installs) – if the org requires admin approval for apps, attacker must target admins directly or rely on social engineering to get approval.
Rate Limiting and CAPTCHA Protection – not a major barrier because the flow uses a small number of legitimate OAuth and login requests rather than brute force.
evasion_considerations: Align the app branding, icon, and description with a known vendor category (HR system, CRM, file sharing) to reduce suspicion on the consent screen.
Request the minimum initial scopes needed (for example, read‑only history) and, where possible, expand or add scopes over time via app updates to avoid alarming admins.
Deliver OAuth links inside existing business threads (for example, via compromised partner email or Slack Connect) to exploit established trust, similar to real‑world spearphishing with cloud links.
Use infrastructure (domains, TLS certificates) that closely resemble legitimate SaaS providers and avoid obvious indicators (URL shorteners, generic domains).
Throttle initial API usage (small volumes of conversations.history/files.list calls) to blend into normal app behavior and avoid detection by anomaly‑based monitoring.
vectors.resulting_access: One or more valid Slack OAuth tokens tied to a malicious app installed in the target workspace. Depending on granted scopes, the attacker gains programmatic access to read channel and DM history, files, user and group metadata, and potentially admin interfaces across the Slack tenant, without ever logging in via the Slack UI.
vectors.comments: This vector directly targets Slack’s app and OAuth model. Crown jewels reachable via this initial access include sensitive channel discussions, DMs, attached documents, and—if admin scopes are granted—org‑wide configuration and governance data (for example, via admin.* and audit‑related APIs). This is the most SaaS‑specific and realistic initial access path for Slack, mirroring documented consent‑phishing campaigns against other collaboration suites.

method_steps.description: Obtain valid credentials or session material for a user whose identity is federated into Slack via SAML SSO (for example, by phishing the IdP login, stealing browser cookies or OAuth tokens on a compromised device, or compromising the IdP itself).
related_capabilities: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
related_interfaces: IdP SAML SSO login pages (external to Slack but referenced in Slack auth docs)
Slack SSO configuration in the admin console
related_data: IdP account username and password or access tokens
MFA device or codes (if needed to satisfy MFA)
SAML assertions that will be accepted by Slack once authentication succeeds
method_steps.notes: MITRE examples for Cloud Accounts show adversaries reusing stolen cloud credentials (for example, Azure AD global admin). The same pattern applies to Slack’s SAML‑backed identities.

method_steps.description: Determine the correct Slack entry point for the victim organization (for example, through public documentation or prior invites) and confirm that the stolen identity is provisioned into Slack via SCIM or prior admin provisioning.
related_interfaces: Slack web client login endpoint for the organization
Admin membership and provisioning UIs/APIs (indirectly, to know who exists)
related_data: workspace_id or org URL
user_id/profile data associated with the target account
method_steps.notes: Because this environment is configured for Domain-Based Registration and SSO‑Only, ordinary self‑registration is not available; the account must already exist via SCIM or admin provisioning.

method_steps.description: From an allowlisted IP range (corporate VPN, compromised internal host, or other permitted address), initiate a Slack login and choose the SSO option. Authenticate to the IdP using the stolen credentials and complete any required MFA challenge.
related_capabilities: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
related_interfaces: Slack login page SSO button/flow
SAML SSO redirect to IdP and back
related_data: SAML assertion for the compromised identity
Slack session cookies and tokens created upon successful SSO
method_steps.notes: Environment constraints MFA Required, SSO-Only Authentication, IP Allowlisting, Rate Limiting, and CAPTCHA Protection all apply. The attacker must already have the means to satisfy MFA and appear from an allowed IP, which typically implies some level of endpoint or IdP compromise outside Slack.

method_steps.description: Once SSO completes, use the established Slack session in the web or desktop client to enumerate accessible channels, DMs, and files, relying on Slack’s normal UI or Web API calls made by the client.
related_capabilities: File sharing and contextual document collaboration
related_interfaces: Slack web or desktop client UI (channels, DMs, search)
Underlying Web API calls invoked by the client (chat.*, conversations.*, files.*)
related_data: channel lists and message histories the user can access
DM conversations for that identity
files shared in those channels/DMs
search results and AI‑powered summaries scoped to the user’s permissions
method_steps.notes: At this point, the attacker has interactive initial access as the compromised cloud identity within the Slack tenant.

capabilities_used: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
File sharing and contextual document collaboration
interfaces_used: Underlying Web API methods used by clients
data_accessed: Slack session cookies and tokens for the compromised user
Channel and DM lists the user can see
Message content and attachments in those channels/DMs
Files and document previews shared in‑scope conversations
Search results across the user’s accessible history
preconditions_required: The target organization uses SAML SSO for Slack (SSO-Only Authentication) and provisions users via SCIM or admin actions so the victim identity already exists in Slack.
The attacker has already compromised the IdP account or device sufficiently to satisfy MFA (MFA Required) and generate valid SAML assertions.
The attacker can appear to Slack as coming from an allowlisted IP (IP Allowlisting), for example by using a compromised corporate endpoint or VPN.
Rate Limiting and CAPTCHA Protection on authentication endpoints prevent brute force; the attacker must rely on prior credential/session theft, not guessing.
constraints_encountered: MFA Required – significantly raises the bar; simple password theft is insufficient without second‑factor compromise or session hijack.
SSO-Only Authentication – no local Slack passwords are available to attack; all identity control is through the IdP.
IP Allowlisting – prevents login from arbitrary Internet addresses; attacker must operate from, or tunnel through, an allowed network.

Domain-Based Registration, Email Verification Required, Admin Approval Required for new registrations – effectively block self‑service creation of accounts for the target domain, forcing the attacker to use already‑provisioned identities.
Rate Limiting and CAPTCHA Protection – make online credential‑stuffing or brute force against Slack or IdP impractical; initial compromise must occur elsewhere.
evasion_considerations: Use the victim’s usual working hours, client platform, and network paths (same VPN or office ranges) to reduce anomalies visible in Slack’s Audit Logs API.
Limit initial activity to passive reading and search, avoiding noisy actions such as mass channel joins or app installs.
Leverage built‑in search and AI‑powered summaries to quickly identify high‑value channels and topics (for example, legal, finance, security) while generating a small number of API calls.
If multiple identities are compromised, prefer ones with broad but plausible access (project managers, IT staff) instead of highly sensitive executives who may be more closely monitored.
vectors.resulting_access: An authenticated, interactive Slack user session in the target organization’s workspace/org, with all the permissions and data visibility of the compromised cloud account (channels, DMs, files, search, and any app interactions bound to that user).
vectors.comments: This vector maps directly to MITRE’s Cloud Accounts pattern: real‑world campaigns regularly use stolen SSO credentials to access collaboration suites. In Slack, the crown jewels exposed will depend heavily on the compromised user’s role—ranging from individual project channels up to org‑wide leadership and security channels if an admin or executive account is taken.

vectors.technique_name: Trusted Relationship (Abusing IdP/SCIM Integrations to Create or Maintain Slack Accounts)

method_steps.description: Compromise the external identity provider or provisioning system that Slack trusts for SAML SSO and/or SCIM (for example, IdP admin account or the service account used to call Slack’s SCIM API).
related_capabilities: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
related_interfaces: IdP admin console (external) that manages Slack SAML configuration
SCIM API endpoints for user and group lifecycle
related_data: SCIM API credentials or bearer tokens
SAML configuration linking IdP groups/attributes to Slack roles
Existing SCIM user/group objects used to model Slack access
method_steps.notes: This mirrors MITRE examples where adversaries compromise a cloud IdP or service principal, then use that position of trust to create cloud accounts or elevate privileges.

method_steps.description: Use the compromised SCIM integration to programmatically create one or more new Slack users that appear legitimate (for example, service accounts or employees) and assign them to groups that map to desired Slack roles and channel access.
related_interfaces: SCIM user and group endpoints (create, update, add group membership)
related_data: New SCIM user objects with corporate email addresses
Group membership assignments that correspond to Slack admin or privileged roles
Provisioning logs indicating successful creation
method_steps.notes: Because the environment is configured for Domain-Based Registration and SSO‑Only Authentication, SCIM is the authoritative path for new accounts; Slack will treat these as fully legitimate users.

method_steps.description: If higher privilege is desired, modify SCIM group mappings or assignments so the new account is placed into groups that grant Slack admin or org‑admin permissions when translated via SAML/SCIM role mappings.
related_interfaces: SCIM group endpoints
Slack admin role-mapping configuration (via admin console or Admin APIs)
related_data: Group membership reflecting admin/owner roles
Role-mapping configuration tying IdP groups to Slack privileges
method_steps.notes: This is analogous to campaigns where compromised cloud IdP admins grant Global Admin or equivalent roles to attacker‑controlled accounts.

method_steps.description: From an allowlisted IP, authenticate to Slack using SSO as the newly provisioned account, completing MFA enrollment as needed (the attacker controls the IdP and can enroll their own MFA or adjust policies).
related_capabilities: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
related_interfaces: Slack SSO login flow
IdP MFA enrollment/approval flows
related_data: Initial SAML assertion for the new account
Slack session cookies and tokens for that user
method_steps.notes: Because the account was provisioned legitimately via SCIM, Email Verification and Admin Approval for new registrations are effectively bypassed.

method_steps.description: Use the new Slack session to verify access and enumerate available channels, admin consoles, and APIs. If the account has admin privileges, it can now view or manage users, channels, app approvals, and security settings across the org.
related_interfaces: Slack admin UI for workspace/org management
Admin.* API endpoints if the attacker also provisions admin‑scoped app tokens
related_data: Org- and workspace-level configuration
User and channel inventories
Potential ability to approve further apps or change security settings
method_steps.notes: Initial access is achieved as soon as the attacker can log into Slack as this SCIM‑provisioned account; use of admin features would be subsequent tactics.

capabilities_used: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
interfaces_used: SCIM API endpoints for users and groups
Slack SSO configuration in the admin console
Slack admin UI and/or Admin.* APIs for role mapping and management
data_accessed: SCIM user and group records for the organization
Newly created Slack user accounts tied to attacker-controlled identities
Group/role mappings that determine Slack admin or owner privileges
Slack sessions and identifiers (user_id, workspace_id, enterprise_id) for the new accounts
Org configuration and channel metadata if elevated privileges are granted
preconditions_required: The target organization has integrated Slack with an IdP and SCIM for automated provisioning, as documented in Slack’s enterprise auth docs.
The attacker has compromised the IdP tenant or SCIM integration credentials sufficiently to create or modify users and groups.
The attacker can satisfy Slack’s IP Allowlisting requirement by operating from an allowed network when logging in as the new account.

The environment uses SSO-Only Authentication and Domain-Based Registration, so external self‑signup is not allowed; SCIM/IdP is the only realistic way to create Slack accounts for the corporate domain.
constraints_encountered: MFA Required – attacker must be able to enroll or bypass MFA for the new account via IdP control.
SSO-Only Authentication – all Slack logins go through the IdP, but this works in the attacker’s favor once the IdP is compromised.
IP Allowlisting – still constrains where the attacker can log in from; they must operate from an allowed range or via a compromised internal host.
Rate Limiting and CAPTCHA Protection – limit brute‑force attempts against IdP or Slack but are irrelevant once IdP compromise has occurred.
Admin Approval Required and Email Verification Required for new registrations – do not typically apply to SCIM‑provisioned accounts and are effectively bypassed via the trusted provisioning channel.
evasion_considerations: Create accounts that resemble legitimate service or contractor accounts, using realistic naming and email conventions, to avoid raising suspicion in user directories and audit logs.
Provision a small number of accounts and avoid giving them overt super‑admin names; instead, grant necessary privileges via group membership that blends into existing patterns.
Time account creation to coincide with normal hiring or onboarding cycles to reduce the chance that unexpected new identities are noticed.
Use SCIM to maintain these accounts (for example, periodically touching them) so that automated deprovisioning or hygiene processes do not remove them.
vectors.resulting_access: One or more Slack user accounts provisioned via the trusted IdP/SCIM integration, optionally with admin‑level roles, that the attacker can log into via SSO and use as fully legitimate identities inside the Slack tenant.
vectors.comments: Here the trusted relationship is between Slack and the organization’s identity infrastructure. Crown jewels exposed are similar to those from a compromised cloud account, but this vector lets an attacker silently introduce or retain identities even if existing Slack accounts are well‑protected, and can be especially damaging when used to mint new admin accounts.

vectors.technique_name: Trusted Relationship (Slack Connect Cross‑Tenant Channels and DMs)

method_steps.description: Obtain or create a Slack workspace under attacker control (for example, a developer sandbox or other workspace) and configure its branding (name, icons, channel names) to resemble a real or plausible partner, customer, or vendor of the target organization.
related_capabilities: Developer tools: Slack CLI, Bolt frameworks, SDKs, and sandboxes
related_interfaces: Developer sandbox organization provisioning (via Slack developer tools)
Workspace settings UI for name and icon
related_data: attacker-controlled workspace_id and enterprise_id (if sandbox is Enterprise)
workspace profile and branding information
method_steps.notes: Slack’s developer sandboxes are explicitly described as full‑featured Enterprise environments, which are sufficient for participating in Slack Connect.

method_steps.description: Using the attacker workspace, initiate a Slack Connect shared channel or external DM invitation targeting users or channels in the victim organization, impersonating a legitimate business relationship.
related_interfaces: Slack Connect channel creation and invite UI in the attacker workspace
External DM invite flows
related_data: Slack Connect invitation metadata (inviting workspace, target email/domain, channel name, message)
Target users’ email addresses or Slack identifiers
method_steps.notes: Real‑world trusted relationship intrusions often begin with a compromised or impersonated service provider; here, the attacker plays that provider role via their own workspace.

method_steps.description: Rely on misconfiguration or overly permissive Slack Connect governance in the target org (for example, broad allowlists or lax approval) and social engineering of target admins/users so that the external Slack Connect invitation is approved and the shared channel/DM is established.
related_interfaces: Slack admin Slack Connect settings UI (domain allowlists, who can create/approve external connections)
End‑user Slack Connect invite approval UI
related_data: Slack Connect policy settings (allowed domains, who can approve)
Audit records of the approval action
method_steps.notes: If admins tightly restrict Slack Connect to known domains and enforce strict approvals, this step becomes much harder; however, business pressure often leads to broad partner connectivity.

method_steps.description: Once the Slack Connect relationship is active, participate in the shared channel/DM from the attacker workspace to read messages, files, canvases, and lists originating from the victim workspace, and to send content or app interactions into that channel.
related_capabilities: File sharing and contextual document collaboration
related_interfaces: Shared channel message UI in both workspaces
File upload UI and link unfurling in the shared channel
Canvas/list surfaces attached to the shared channel
related_data: shared_channel_id linking both organizations’ channels
messages and threads sent by victim users into the shared channel
files and document links shared in the connect channel
canvases and lists attached to the shared channel
method_steps.notes: From the victim’s perspective, the attacker appears as an external collaborator from a seemingly legitimate partner workspace.

method_steps.description: Optionally, add attacker‑controlled apps or workflows into the Slack Connect channel on the attacker side, so that messages and files from the victim side are also streamed to attacker infrastructure via Events API or workflow connectors.
related_interfaces: Web API and Events API endpoints for apps installed in the attacker workspace
Workflow Builder configuration for triggers bound to the shared channel
related_data: event payloads for messages and files in the shared channel
workflow execution logs and connector outputs sent to external systems
method_steps.notes: This amplifies data collection but is not required for initial access; initial access is achieved once the attacker can read messages in the shared channel directly in their workspace.

capabilities_used: File sharing and contextual document collaboration
Developer tools: Slack CLI, Bolt frameworks, SDKs, and sandboxes
interfaces_used: Slack Connect shared channel/DM creation and invite UI
Slack Connect admin settings (allowed domains, approval workflows)
Events API and Workflow Builder triggers bound to shared channels
data_accessed: Messages and threads in the Slack Connect shared channels/DMs originating from the victim workspace
Files and external document links shared by the victim in those conversations
Canvases and lists attached to shared channels that the victim uses for project documentation or task tracking
Connection and invitation metadata (partner workspace_id, domains, approval times)
preconditions_required: The target organization actively uses Slack Connect to collaborate with external organizations.
Slack Connect governance is configured to allow new external connections from domains the attacker can control or impersonate, or approvals are lax enough to be social‑engineered.
The attacker can obtain or create a Slack workspace (for example, a developer sandbox) and configure it to look like a plausible partner.
At least one target admin or user is willing (or tricked) to approve the Slack Connect invitation.
constraints_encountered: Slack Connect governance – organizations can require admin approval for all external connections and restrict allowed domains; strong governance significantly reduces feasibility.
IP Allowlisting – applies separately to each workspace. The attacker only needs to meet IP restrictions for their own workspace; Slack Connect traffic is relayed by Slack’s backend.
MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication – apply to users in each workspace but are not obstacles once the attacker controls their own workspace; victim org users authenticate normally.
evasion_considerations: Closely mimic the branding, domain, and contact patterns of a real vendor or customer already known to the target, to reduce scrutiny of Slack Connect invitations.
Propose collaboration on a narrowly scoped project and use plausible channel names (for example, #customer‑implementation‑projectx) so the shared channel does not draw attention.
Limit data collection to reading and occasional benign participation; avoid aggressive file requests or unusual automation that might cause security review.
If possible, piggyback on an already‑compromised real partner workspace rather than creating a new one, mirroring documented MSP and cloud‑hopper intrusions.
vectors.resulting_access: Ongoing presence as an external member in one or more Slack Connect shared channels and DMs with the victim organization, providing read/write access to all content posted there (messages, files, canvases, lists) without direct membership in the victim’s internal workspaces.
vectors.comments: This vector leverages Slack’s explicit cross‑tenant trust feature. While access is limited to shared channels/DMs, organizations often discuss deals, incidents, and integration details there. For many targets—especially those heavily interacting with vendors and customers—these shared spaces can contain crown‑jewel data such as contracts, incident coordination, and sensitive customer context.

vectors.technique_name: Valid Accounts (Compromised High‑Privilege Admin or Governance Integrations)

method_steps.description: Identify or infer third‑party or internal services that integrate with Slack using high‑privilege scopes (for example, SIEM connectors using the Audit Logs API, eDiscovery tools using Legal Holds API, or admin automation apps using admin.* APIs).
related_capabilities: Audit Logs API and Admin Oversight API
Data export, discovery, and legal holds
related_interfaces: Audit Logs API documentation and endpoints
Admin Oversight API documentation and endpoints
Legal Holds API documentation and endpoints
Admin.* API documentation
related_data: List of integrations and vendors from public documentation or victim org materials
Assumed presence of high‑privilege OAuth tokens within those services
method_steps.notes: This mirrors campaigns where adversaries target MSPs or monitoring providers first, then pivot into customer environments via their privileged access.

method_steps.description: Compromise the external service or internal platform that holds the Slack integration (for example, breach the SIEM tenant, DLP platform, or admin automation server) and locate stored Slack OAuth tokens or API credentials with admin/audit/legal scopes.
related_capabilities: OAuth-based authentication and tokens for apps
Security monitoring, logging, and incident management
related_interfaces: Service’s configuration UI or secret store where Slack tokens are configured
Slack OAuth client and token metadata within that service
related_data: OAuth access tokens for Admin, Audit Logs, Admin Oversight, or Legal Holds APIs
Client_id/client_secret pairs for admin-focused Slack apps
method_steps.notes: From Slack’s perspective these are valid, previously authorized accounts (service principals) with powerful scopes.

method_steps.description: From infrastructure or IP ranges associated with the compromised service (which are already allowlisted by the victim organization for Slack API access), use the recovered tokens to perform initial low‑volume API calls such as auth.test and minimal Audit Logs or Oversight queries to validate access.
related_capabilities: Audit Logs API and Admin Oversight API
Web API for core Slack operations
related_interfaces: auth.test Web API method
Audit Logs API endpoints
Admin Oversight API endpoints
Legal Holds API endpoints
related_data: workspace_id and enterprise_id for the victim org
Confirmation of scopes and app_id associated with the token
Initial audit or oversight records returned from test queries
method_steps.notes: Environment constraints like MFA and SSO do not apply to these API calls, which rely solely on OAuth tokens; IP Allowlisting is satisfied by using the compromised provider’s infrastructure.

method_steps.description: Once validated, the attacker can start systematically querying governance APIs (within rate limits) to enumerate users, channels, admin actions, and held content or to trigger exports, achieving broad initial access to Slack metadata and, in some configurations, message content.
related_capabilities: Audit Logs API and Admin Oversight API
Data export, discovery, and legal holds
related_interfaces: Audit Logs API query endpoints
Admin Oversight query endpoints
Legal Holds API (list holds, scopes)
Data export admin UI/APIs (if exposed)
related_data: Audit event history (logins, admin changes, app installs)
Channel and membership metadata
Selected messages and files subject to oversight or legal hold
Definitions of legal holds and preserved content scopes
method_steps.notes: Initial access in this vector is achieved when the attacker successfully issues any governance API request using the compromised token; further bulk collection is a later collection tactic.

capabilities_used: Audit Logs API and Admin Oversight API
Data export, discovery, and legal holds
OAuth-based authentication and tokens for apps
Security monitoring, logging, and incident management
data_accessed: High-privilege OAuth tokens for Slack governance and admin APIs
Workspace and org identifiers
Audit event streams (logins, admin changes, app approvals, security events)
Channel and membership metadata across the org
Message and file content exposed via Admin Oversight or export mechanisms
Scopes and configuration of legal holds preserving specific content
preconditions_required: The victim organization has deployed one or more high‑privilege Slack integrations (for example, SIEM connectors using Audit Logs API, eDiscovery tools using Legal Holds API, or admin automation apps).
The attacker has successfully compromised the environment or account hosting that integration (for example, via separate attacks on the MSP, SIEM vendor, or internal automation platform).
Slack API calls from that environment are allowed by IP Allowlisting and recognized as legitimate by Slack.
The integration stores long‑lived OAuth tokens or credentials for Slack that the attacker can retrieve.
constraints_encountered: IP Allowlisting – the attacker must operate from the provider’s or internal platform’s network ranges that the org has allowlisted for Slack API access.
MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication – do not apply to OAuth token usage; they only governed the original human authorization of the app.
Rate Limiting – constrains how quickly large audit or oversight datasets can be pulled; the attacker must pace requests to avoid rate‑limit errors and detection.
Admin Approval Required (for apps) – limits which apps can hold these scopes in the first place; however, once an approved integration is compromised, its tokens remain valid until revoked.
evasion_considerations: Reuse the compromised service’s existing API client identifiers and user‑agent patterns so traffic continues to look like legitimate SIEM/DLP/eDiscovery activity.
Query governance APIs in patterns and volumes similar to the original integration (for example, incremental pulls rather than full historical dumps) to avoid spikes.
If possible, restrict activity to read‑only APIs initially and avoid admin.* calls that change configuration, which are more visible and may generate alerts.
Leverage downstream SIEM or archive stores already populated with Slack data to minimize direct, new API access against Slack itself.
vectors.resulting_access: Programmatic access to Slack’s high‑privilege governance and admin APIs via valid service accounts (OAuth tokens) originally granted to trusted third‑party or internal integrations, enabling broad visibility into users, channels, admin events, and, where configured, preserved message content and exports.
vectors.comments: This vector combines Valid Accounts with a Trusted Relationship to MSPs or governance vendors. The crown jewels here include complete audit trails, org‑wide channel and membership maps, and in some deployments large volumes of preserved or exported messages/files—all accessible without ever logging into the Slack UI as a human user.

preconditions_required: Slack would need to expose customer‑usable default accounts or factory credentials (for example, built‑in admin users with known passwords or API keys) for workspaces or orgs.
constraints_encountered: Authentication is explicitly documented as relying on SAML SSO, SCIM, and user‑managed credentials; there is no mention of built‑in default user or admin accounts with static passwords.
Enterprise administration (workspace owners, org owners) is rooted in provisioned identities and IdP integrations, not in product‑defined default superusers.
Admin and governance APIs require OAuth tokens with explicitly granted scopes; there is no reference to default API tokens or keys.
vectors.comments: MITRE’s Default Accounts technique typically involves factory‑set device or application accounts (such as `admin/admin` logins or hardcoded DB credentials). The analyzed Slack documentation describes SSO, SCIM, and OAuth‑based identities, but does not indicate any customer‑accessible default Slack users or pre‑shared admin credentials. Without evidence of such accounts, leveraging Default Accounts for initial access to a Slack tenant is not realistic in this model.

initial_access.summary:
Applicable initial access techniques for Slack in this environment are dominated by:

• Spearphishing Link / consent phishing against Slack’s OAuth app model, yielding first‑class app tokens into a tenant.
• Cloud Accounts and Valid Accounts, where attackers log into Slack using compromised SSO‑backed identities or seized high‑privilege service accounts.
• Trusted Relationships, both via identity integrations (IdP/SCIM) and cross‑tenant collaboration (Slack Connect), as well as via third‑party governance and monitoring integrations with powerful admin/audit scopes.

Environment constraints (SSO‑Only, MFA Required, IP Allowlisting, restricted registration) significantly impede brute‑force and self‑service signup attacks, pushing realistic adversaries toward abusing trusted integrations, app consent flows, and existing privileged accounts rather than attacking Slack’s core auth flows directly. The main crown jewels exposed through these vectors are internal conversations (channels and DMs), shared files and canvases, enterprise search/AI context, and, for governance integrations, comprehensive audit and legal‑hold datasets that reflect the organization’s entire Slack usage history.

method_steps.description: Using the already-compromised standard Slack user account (which has successfully authenticated via SSO and MFA), the attacker signs in to the Slack web or desktop client for the target workspace to obtain a normal channel and DM view.

preconditions_required: Attacker controls at least one valid Slack user account in the target workspace (credentials, session, or device), with SSO and MFA requirements already satisfied or bypassed during initial access.
The compromised user has membership in at least some non-trivial set of channels so that enumeration yields meaningful coverage.
The environment does not completely hide user profile information and channel member lists from regular users (standard Slack behavior per documentation).
constraints_encountered: MFA Required – makes compromising additional accounts harder but does not prevent enumeration from an already-compromised account.
SSO-Only Authentication – limits how new accounts can be created or reused, but once a session is active it does not restrict UI-based discovery.
IP Allowlisting – attacker may need to operate from an approved corporate/VPN IP or a previously trusted device to maintain access.
Rate Limiting – primarily affects automated API calls; normal UI-driven search and navigation are unlikely to hit limits if done at human pace.
evasion_considerations: Keep activity within normal user behavior patterns: browse channels gradually, avoid rapidly opening hundreds of channels in a short time window.
Use search sparingly and over a longer period ("low-and-slow"), mixing targeted queries with routine work-related searches.
Do not enable or install new apps from the compromised account, which could trigger admin review; rely entirely on existing UI capabilities.
vectors.information_discovered: A detailed inventory of all users and channels visible to the compromised account, including which users participate in which channels, rough organizational structure inferred from channel naming, and identification of high-value individuals (admins, security staff, executives) and sensitive teams.
vectors.comments: This is the baseline, least-privileged account discovery path and will exist in almost every Slack deployment regardless of admin APIs or SCIM configuration.

preconditions_required: Target organization is on a plan that exposes SCIM and Admin APIs (Enterprise tier, per documented assumptions).
Attacker has compromised an Org Owner/Admin identity or an app/service account with SCIM and admin.* OAuth scopes.
Attacker can reach Slack’s admin and SCIM endpoints from an IP that is allowed by any corporate IP allowlisting rules.
Admin approvals for high-privilege apps have already been granted; the attacker is reusing an existing integration or admin account, not attempting to install a new one.
constraints_encountered: MFA Required – significantly raises the bar for initial compromise of admin identities, but has limited impact once a valid admin session or token is stolen.
SSO-Only Authentication – prevents direct password attacks on Slack accounts; enumeration must leverage SCIM/Admin APIs or existing sessions rather than repeated logins.
IP Allowlisting – SCIM and Admin API calls may only succeed from specific corporate or VPN ranges, forcing the attacker to route traffic through those networks.
Rate Limiting – Slack Web, Admin, SCIM, and Audit Logs APIs enforce rate limits; bulk enumeration must be batched and throttled to avoid errors and suspicious spikes.
evasion_considerations: Throttle SCIM and Admin API requests to mimic legitimate provisioning or audit tooling patterns instead of rapid-fire enumeration.
Prefer using an already-deployed admin or identity integration (e.g., a security or HR tool) whose traffic to SCIM/Admin APIs is expected, rather than creating a new integration.
Query incrementally (e.g., by lastModified) rather than pulling the full directory repeatedly, to reduce noise in logs.
vectors.information_discovered: A complete, machine-readable inventory of all Slack user accounts across the Enterprise organization, including their identity attributes, per-workspace membership, and indications of which accounts hold elevated privileges or are actively used for administration.
vectors.comments: This represents the highest-fidelity account discovery path and is directly analogous to cloud IAM enumeration (e.g., Azure AD or AWS IAM).

capabilities_used: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
Security monitoring, logging, and incident management
interfaces_used: Admin security and authentication settings UI. (https://slack.com/enterprise/; https://slack.com/help/categories/200122103)
Slack Trust Center and compliance pages. (https://slack.com/trust/; https://slack.com/trust/compliance)
Authentication overview for apps and tokens. (https://docs.slack.dev/authentication/)
data_accessed: Whether SAML SSO is enabled and/or required for all users
Whether two-factor authentication is enforced and for which users
Any EMM requirements for devices accessing Slack
Whether local Slack passwords are permitted or if SSO-only is enforced
High-level session, login, and token management behaviors as documented by Slack
preconditions_required: The attacker has compromised a Workspace or Org Admin account with rights to view security/authentication settings.
The environment allows admins to view (not necessarily edit) authentication configuration in the admin console.
Public Slack Security Practices and Trust Center documentation are accessible (they are unauthenticated).
constraints_encountered: SSO-Only Authentication – in many Enterprise environments, Slack may be configured to require SSO, which means detailed password complexity rules live in the IdP and may not be visible from Slack itself.
MFA Required – strong MFA enforcement limits the usefulness of any discovered password acceptance paths.
IP Allowlisting – may restrict from where the admin console can be accessed but does not block reading configuration once logged in.
evasion_considerations: Viewing security settings in the admin console is a normal admin activity; avoid frequent changes or test toggles that could attract attention.
Access public documentation (Security Practices, Trust Center) anonymously rather than from the compromised admin account to reduce correlation.
vectors.information_discovered: An understanding of how authentication to Slack is enforced in the target environment—whether sign-in is SSO-only, whether 2FA is mandatory, whether EMM is required for mobile, and whether any local Slack passwords are accepted—giving the attacker a clear picture of which credential and session attacks are viable.
vectors.comments: Because Slack is commonly configured as SSO-only for Enterprise, this vector often yields "SSO + MFA required, no local passwords" rather than detailed password complexity, but that information is still strategically important.

vectors.technique_name: Cloud Service Discovery (Apps, AI, and Workflows)

method_steps.description: Using a compromised Workspace/Org Admin account, the attacker opens the Slack app management UI to list all installed apps, focusing on bots, AI assistants, and high-privilege integrations (e.g., those with broad message/file or admin scopes).
related_interfaces: Slack Marketplace web UI and in-client app directory. (https://slack.com/marketplace/)
Admin app management UI. (https://slack.com/help/articles/7887743766291-Add-internal-app-collaborators)
related_data: app_id and metadata for all installed apps
per-workspace installation records and approver identities
high-level descriptions of app purpose and connected external services
method_steps.notes: MITRE examples of cloud service discovery often enumerate applications and services via provider consoles; this step does the same within Slack.

method_steps.description: The attacker queries app approval and Admin APIs (if available) to programmatically enumerate all apps, their requested OAuth scopes, and approval/restriction states across the entire organization.
related_capabilities: OAuth-based authentication and tokens for apps
related_interfaces: Admin app approval APIs. (https://docs.slack.dev/admins/managing-app-approvals)
App management and distribution API surfaces. (https://docs.slack.dev/app-management/distribution/)
Scopes and permissions reference. (https://docs.slack.dev/reference/scopes)
related_data: per-app lists of requested and granted OAuth scopes
approval, restriction, and pending-request status for each app
org-wide mapping of apps to workspaces and installers
method_steps.notes: This is analogous to using Azure or AWS APIs to list applications and their permissions; here, it reveals which integrations can read messages, files, channels, or admin data.

method_steps.description: The attacker enumerates Workflow Builder workflows via the Workflow Builder UI and any available admin views, capturing triggers, steps, and third-party connectors to understand automated data flows between Slack and external SaaS services.
related_interfaces: Workflow Builder UI and documentation. (https://slack.com/help/articles/360035692513-Guide-to-Slack-Workflow-Builder)
Workflows vs apps comparison (governance characteristics). (https://docs.slack.dev/workflows/comparing-workflows-apps/)
related_data: workflow definitions including triggers, steps, and connected tools
channels, users, and apps referenced in workflow steps
execution logs or metadata where visible
method_steps.notes: Workflows can silently move data between Slack and external services and are thus key cloud services to discover.

method_steps.description: The attacker identifies AI agents and Slack AI features by searching for Agentforce and other AI apps in the app directory, checking whether Slack AI is enabled in admin/billing UIs, and reviewing AI-related app manifests and scopes (e.g., assistant:write and message/file read scopes).
related_capabilities: Agentforce and AI agents in Slack
Slack AI for summaries and assistance
related_interfaces: Agentforce and AI agents overview. (https://slack.com/ai-agents/)
AI and agents developer docs. (https://docs.slack.dev/ai/; https://docs.slack.dev/ai/developing-ai-apps)
Slack Enterprise/Work OS pages describing Slack AI. (https://slack.com/enterprise/; https://slack.com/work-operating-system/)
related_data: list of AI agents installed in the org and their scopes
Slack AI enablement status and coverage (which workspaces/channels benefit from AI recaps/search)
assistant thread and streaming capabilities used by AI apps
method_steps.notes: AI agents often have broad access to messages, files, canvases, and lists; discovering them is critical for understanding potential high-impact paths.

method_steps.description: Using the Audit Logs API and Admin Oversight API where available, the attacker examines which apps, workflows, and agents have historically accessed or modified content in sensitive channels, canvases, and lists to prioritize the most valuable services to target.
related_capabilities: Audit Logs API and Admin Oversight API
Security monitoring, logging, and incident management
related_interfaces: Audit Logs API. (https://docs.slack.dev/admins/audit-logs-api/)
Admin Oversight API. (https://docs.slack.dev/admins/admin-oversight-api)
related_data: audit events for app installations, workflow creation, and agent activity
oversight-accessible channel and message metadata linked to specific apps/agents
timestamps and actors/sites associated with high-privilege automation
method_steps.notes: Similar to enumerating GuardDuty, CloudTrail, or other cloud security services, but focused on discovering which Slack-integrated services actively touch high-value data.

capabilities_used: OAuth-based authentication and tokens for apps
Agentforce and AI agents in Slack
Slack AI for summaries and assistance
Audit Logs API and Admin Oversight API
Security monitoring, logging, and incident management
interfaces_used: Slack Marketplace web UI and in-client app directory. (https://slack.com/marketplace/)
data_accessed: List of all installed apps, including internal and Marketplace apps
OAuth scopes and permissions requested/granted to each app
App approval status and any restrictions or allowlists/denylists
Definitions of all Workflow Builder workflows and their connectors
Inventory of AI agents (Agentforce and others) and their scopes/skills
Audit records of app, workflow, and agent activity in the environment
preconditions_required: The attacker has compromised an identity with access to app management and, ideally, Admin APIs (Workspace/Org Admin or an app with admin.* scopes).
Workflow Builder is enabled in at least some workspaces to make workflow discovery meaningful.
AI agents or Slack AI features are enabled in the environment for AI-related discovery to yield results.
constraints_encountered: Admin Approval Required (for apps) – severely restricts the attacker’s ability to introduce new enumeration or backdoor apps, forcing reliance on existing apps or admin APIs.
Rate Limiting – Web, Admin, and Audit Logs APIs enforce rate limits; enumeration of large app and workflow inventories must be batched.
IP Allowlisting – may restrict from where app management and admin APIs can be invoked.
evasion_considerations: Favor using existing admin or security tooling (e.g., SIEM connectors, governance apps) to pull app/workflow inventories instead of creating new apps that may trigger reviews.
Space out API calls and UI exploration over time to resemble normal admin hygiene rather than a one-time massive sweep.
Avoid changing app or workflow configurations; read-only discovery is less likely to raise alerts.
vectors.information_discovered: A comprehensive picture of all cloud services integrated with Slack—bots, AI agents, internal apps, third-party SaaS connectors, and no-code workflows—along with their scopes and where they operate, highlighting which services have access to sensitive Slack data and external systems.
vectors.comments: This vector is central for understanding how Slack functions as a hub in the broader SaaS ecosystem and where compromise of a single integration could yield outsized access.

vectors.technique_name: Cloud Service Discovery (Governance, Logging, and Encryption)

method_steps.description: Using a compromised Org Admin account, the attacker reviews the admin console sections for security, compliance, and data management to identify whether Audit Logs API, Admin Oversight API, data exports, legal holds, and Enterprise Key Management (EKM) are enabled.
related_capabilities: Security monitoring, logging, and incident management
Data export, discovery, and legal holds
related_interfaces: Workspace administration UI – security and governance settings. (https://slack.com/help/categories/200122103)
Enterprise and security documentation. (https://slack.com/enterprise/; https://slack.com/security-practices/; https://slack.com/trust/compliance)
EKM overview. (https://slack.com/enterprise-key-management/)
related_data: indicators of whether Audit Logs API and legal holds are enabled
EKM enablement and key scope (org/workspace/channel/time/file), if visible
data residency region and compliance modes (e.g., HIPAA-enabled)
method_steps.notes: Similar to identifying services like CloudTrail, GuardDuty, or KMS in cloud environments, but focused on Slack’s governance stack.

method_steps.description: The attacker uses the Audit Logs API to enumerate available event types and recent events, confirming that admin, security, and app-related activities are being logged and assessing how observable their future actions may be.
related_capabilities: Audit Logs API and Admin Oversight API
Security monitoring, logging, and incident management
related_interfaces: Audit Logs API. (https://docs.slack.dev/admins/audit-logs-api/)
related_data: audit event schemas and categories available to the tenant
sample events showing who performs configuration changes, exports, and app installations
method_steps.notes: This parallels adversaries inspecting CloudTrail or Azure activity logs to understand detection coverage and tune their TTPs.

method_steps.description: The attacker queries the Legal Holds API and export tooling to list any active legal holds and prior exports, revealing which users, channels, and timeframes are under special preservation, and how broadly export capabilities are used.
related_capabilities: Data export, discovery, and legal holds
related_interfaces: Legal Holds API. (https://docs.slack.dev/admins/legal-holds-api/)
Admin data export tools. (https://slack.com/help/articles/204897248-Guide-to-Slack-data-exports)
related_data: definitions of active and historical legal holds (users, channels, timeframes)
metadata about prior exports (who initiated them, what they covered)
method_steps.notes: Awareness of legal holds can inform the attacker which data is preserved regardless of retention settings and where their activity may be examined later.

method_steps.description: If Enterprise Key Management is enabled, the attacker correlates Slack-side EKM configuration with AWS KMS, CloudWatch, and CloudTrail information (if they also have access in the customer AWS account) to understand how encryption keys are organized and logged.
related_interfaces: EKM documentation and configuration interface. (https://slack.com/enterprise-key-management/)
related_data: mapping of customer-managed keys to Slack data segments (org, workspace, channel, timeframe, file)
CloudWatch/CloudTrail key-usage logs where accessible to the attacker
method_steps.notes: This is analogous to adversaries discovering KMS key structures and logs to plan around or abuse encryption controls.

capabilities_used: Security monitoring, logging, and incident management
Audit Logs API and Admin Oversight API
Data export, discovery, and legal holds
interfaces_used: Workspace administration UI – security, export, and governance settings. (https://slack.com/help/categories/200122103)
Slack Trust Center and compliance documentation. (https://slack.com/trust/; https://slack.com/trust/compliance)
data_accessed: Configuration indicating whether Audit Logs, Admin Oversight, Legal Holds, exports, and EKM are enabled
Audit event data about admin, security, and app activities
Definitions and scopes of legal holds across users and channels
History and metadata of data exports from the tenant
Information about how customer-managed encryption keys are applied to Slack data and how key usage is logged
preconditions_required: The organization is on an Enterprise tier that exposes Audit Logs, Legal Holds, and potentially EKM features.
The attacker has compromised an Org Admin or similarly privileged identity with access to governance UIs and APIs.
If correlating with KMS logs, the attacker also has some level of access to the customer’s AWS account used for EKM.
constraints_encountered: MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication complicate initial compromise of high-privilege admins but not subsequent inspection of governance settings.
IP Allowlisting may limit from where governance APIs and UIs can be accessed.
Rate Limiting on Audit Logs and Legal Holds APIs restricts how aggressively the attacker can pull full histories.
evasion_considerations: Read but do not modify governance settings to avoid generating anomalous configuration change events.
Query only recent audit and legal hold data initially to minimize volume and attention, expanding gradually if needed.
If possible, piggyback on existing security tooling or SIEM pipelines (e.g., reuse API credentials already feeding logs out of Slack) to avoid creating new API consumers.
vectors.information_discovered: A clear map of the tenant’s governance and security services—what is logged, what is preserved under legal holds, how data exports are used, and whether customer-managed keys protect Slack data—allowing the attacker to understand both detection surface and long-term data persistence.
vectors.comments: This vector is especially important for sophisticated adversaries who want to balance stealth with persistence, and to know which actions are most likely to show up in downstream SIEMs and eDiscovery.

method_steps.description: Using a compromised Org Admin or Workspace Owner account, the attacker accesses the primary Slack admin console dashboards to view high-level summaries of workspaces, members, apps, and security posture, using these aggregated views instead of individual API calls.
related_capabilities: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
related_interfaces: Workspace and org administration UI. (https://slack.com/help/categories/200122103)
Slack Connect security and admin resources. (https://slack.com/resources/slack-for-admins/slack-connect-security)
Admin app management UI. (https://slack.com/help/articles/7887743766291-Add-internal-app-collaborators)
related_data: aggregated counts of members and workspaces (where shown)
summary lists of installed apps and their status
summary indicators of Slack Connect usage and allowed domains
authentication configuration status (SSO/2FA enabled)
method_steps.notes: Equivalent to using cloud provider dashboards (e.g., AWS console, GCP Security Command Center) to quickly understand environment shape without low-level enumeration.

method_steps.description: From the same admin console, the attacker views Slack Connect, app, and workflow sections to understand the scale of external collaboration, the volume of installed apps, and whether Workflow Builder is actively used, all from aggregate UI views.
related_interfaces: Slack Connect governance UI. (https://slack.com/resources/slack-for-admins/slack-connect-security)
Slack Marketplace/app management within the admin console. (https://slack.com/marketplace/; https://docs.slack.dev/app-management/distribution/)
Workflow Builder UI entry points. (https://slack.com/help/articles/360035692513-Guide-to-Slack-Workflow-Builder)
related_data: lists or counts of Slack Connect channels and connected external domains
high-level app inventory as shown in admin UIs
number and status of workflows configured in the org
method_steps.notes: These dashboards avoid the need for detailed API queries to answer basic scoping questions such as "How many external partners are connected?" or "How app-heavy is this workspace?"

method_steps.description: The attacker notes from dashboard and settings overviews which advanced security and compliance features are turned on (e.g., Slack AI add-ons, EKM, legal hold capabilities, SSO enforcement), using that to prioritize other discovery activities and potential attack paths.
related_capabilities: Slack AI for summaries and assistance
Data export, discovery, and legal holds
related_interfaces: Enterprise admin and billing/security configuration UI. (https://slack.com/enterprise/; https://slack.com/security-practices/; https://slack.com/trust/compliance)
related_data: flags indicating purchase/enablement of Slack AI and other premium capabilities
EKM enablement and general scoping information
availability and plan-level status of legal holds and advanced export features
method_steps.notes: The attacker uses high-level UI indicators to choose where to spend time (e.g., if EKM is present, investigate encryption/logging; if Slack AI is enabled, investigate AI agents and summaries).

capabilities_used: Slack AI for summaries and assistance
Data export, discovery, and legal holds
Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
interfaces_used: Enterprise, security, and compliance admin/billing interfaces. (https://slack.com/enterprise/; https://slack.com/security-practices/; https://slack.com/trust/compliance)
data_accessed: High-level counts of users, workspaces, apps, Slack Connect relationships, and workflows (as exposed in admin dashboards)
Summary view of authentication configuration (SSO, 2FA, EMM enforcement)
Indicators of whether Slack AI, EKM, legal holds, and advanced export features are available and enabled
Surface-level information about which external domains and apps are allowed in the environment
preconditions_required: The attacker has control of a Workspace Owner/Admin or Org Owner/Admin account with access to the admin console dashboards.
The organization uses Enterprise or advanced plans where richer admin dashboards and governance settings are present.
Any IP allowlisting policies allow access to the admin console from at least one location the attacker can use.
constraints_encountered: MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication increase difficulty of obtaining admin access but do not limit dashboard viewing once authenticated.
IP Allowlisting may require using a specific corporate/VPN IP to reach the admin console.
Admin Approval Required (for new user registrations) may reduce the number of admin accounts available to target, but once compromised, the dashboards are fully visible.
evasion_considerations: Rely on read-only dashboard views; avoid changing configuration values from within those screens.
Access dashboards at times and frequencies consistent with normal admin workflows (e.g., business hours, monthly governance reviews).
If multiple admin accounts exist, avoid logging into all of them; stick to one compromised admin identity to reduce anomaly signals.
vectors.information_discovered: A concise, dashboard-level understanding of the Slack tenant: approximate size and structure, volume of external collaboration, prevalence of apps and workflows, and high-level security/compliance posture, all obtained via built-in admin consoles rather than detailed API enumeration.
vectors.comments: Cloud Service Dashboard in this context is about the attacker exploiting Slack’s own admin and governance UIs as a management dashboard for rapid situational awareness.

discovery.summary:
Slack exposes rich discovery surfaces to anyone who gains access, especially at admin or SCIM/Admin-API levels. From a single compromised standard user, an attacker can already enumerate visible users, channels, and Slack Connect participants via the normal UI and search. With compromised admin identities or high-privilege app tokens, they can pivot to SCIM and Admin APIs to perform full cloud account and cloud group discovery, mapping every Slack account, its group memberships, and its effective privileges across all workspaces and the Enterprise organization.

Using admin consoles and APIs, an attacker can also enumerate Slack Connect external organizations and users, installed apps and AI agents, Workflow Builder automations, and governance services such as Audit Logs, Legal Holds, data exports, and Enterprise Key Management. Admin dashboards act as a cloud service dashboard, giving quick, high-level insight into tenant size, external collaboration, app footprint, and security posture without heavy API use. Environmental constraints like MFA, SSO-only authentication, IP allowlisting, and rate limiting significantly raise the bar for initial compromise and high-volume automation, but once an attacker controls an appropriate user or admin account, all of the described discovery vectors are realistically achievable with Slack’s documented capabilities.

method_steps.description: Prepare or compromise a Slack app (typically a Bolt app or comparable custom app) that declares OAuth scopes allowing it to read and/or write messages, access channels, and optionally use AI/streaming features in the target workspace.
related_capabilities: Web API for core Slack operations
Interactivity: shortcuts, slash commands, and interactive components
OAuth-based authentication and tokens for apps
App distribution and Slack Marketplace listing
Developer tools: Slack CLI, Bolt frameworks, SDKs, and sandboxes
related_interfaces: Slack app management and distribution interfaces (https://docs.slack.dev/app-management/distribution/)
OAuth 2.0 install and token endpoints for apps (https://docs.slack.dev/authentication/installing-with-oauth)
Scopes and permissions reference (https://docs.slack.dev/reference/scopes)
Slack Marketplace listing and install pages (https://slack.com/marketplace/)
Slack CLI and SDK tooling (https://docs.slack.dev/tools/, https://docs.slack.dev/tools/slack-cli/)
related_data: App manifest defining requested scopes, events, and surfaces
OAuth client_id and client_secret
Requested OAuth scopes such as chat:write, channels:history, users:read, files:read
method_steps.notes: From an execution perspective, the critical outcome of this step is that the app will later receive events/interactions and hold OAuth tokens that can be used to drive Slack Web API calls.

method_steps.description: Obtain valid OAuth tokens for the app in the target workspace (bot/user/app tokens) by completing the OAuth installation flow or by abusing previously compromised tokens.
related_capabilities: OAuth-based authentication and tokens for apps
App distribution and Slack Marketplace listing
related_interfaces: OAuth 2.0 authorization and token endpoints (https://docs.slack.dev/authentication/installing-with-oauth)
App distribution settings in app configuration (https://docs.slack.dev/app-management/distribution/)
related_data: Bot/user/app OAuth access tokens bound to the target workspace
Installation records associating the app with the workspace and installing user
Granted scopes recorded for the installation
method_steps.notes: MFA, SSO-only authentication, domain-based registration, email verification, and admin approval for new users constrain how the attacker originally obtained the account or app, but once tokens exist they can be used directly against the Web API without re-passing those controls.

method_steps.description: Configure the app to receive triggers from Slack (Events API, slash commands, shortcuts, and/or block_actions) so that attacker-controlled code is invoked whenever relevant user or system activity occurs.
related_capabilities: Interactivity: shortcuts, slash commands, and interactive components
App surfaces and Block Kit UI framework
related_interfaces: Events API subscription and delivery endpoints (https://docs.slack.dev/apis/events-api/)
Interactivity request URLs for slash commands, shortcuts, and block_actions (https://docs.slack.dev/interactivity/)
Assistant thread events such as assistant_thread_started and message.im for AI-style apps (https://docs.slack.dev/ai/developing-ai-apps#app-flow)
related_data: Events API payloads containing team_id, channel_id, user_id, message text, and other context
Slash command and shortcut payloads including free-form command text
Block Kit interaction payloads describing which button/menu was clicked
AI assistant thread events and context objects (for AI-enabled apps)
method_steps.notes: This step establishes Slack as a remote trigger surface: whenever a subscribed event or interaction occurs, the attacker’s backend code will execute.

method_steps.description: On each incoming event or interaction, execute arbitrary application logic in the app’s external runtime (for example, custom scripts, database queries, calls to external LLMs or SaaS APIs) under full attacker control.
related_capabilities: Developer tools: Slack CLI, Bolt frameworks, SDKs, and sandboxes
Web API for core Slack operations
related_interfaces: Bolt or SDK handlers running on attacker-controlled infrastructure (referenced from https://docs.slack.dev/tools/)
Any external APIs or services the app chooses to call (not directly a Slack interface but orchestrated via app code)
related_data: Message content and metadata pulled from event payloads or via Web API lookups
User and channel identifiers used to scope actions or correlate with external data
Any secrets or tokens the attacker chooses to store in their backend
method_steps.notes: MITRE’s Cloud API examples (e.g., Pacu using AWS CLI) map here to the attacker’s own code leveraging Slack’s APIs. The actual compute runs on attacker infrastructure; Slack acts as the command input/output channel.

method_steps.description: Use the Slack Web API to execute commands inside the Slack environment—posting or streaming messages, reading channel history, modifying membership, or interacting with app surfaces—based on the attacker’s code logic.
related_capabilities: Web API for core Slack operations
App surfaces and Block Kit UI framework
related_interfaces: Web API HTTP endpoints, including chat.postMessage, chat.update, conversations.* (https://docs.slack.dev/apis/web-api/)
Streaming endpoints chat.startStream, chat.appendStream, chat.stopStream (https://docs.slack.dev/ai/developing-ai-apps#streaming)
related_data: Channel and DM identifiers targeted for message send or modification
Message_ts values used to update or thread messages
Channel membership and metadata retrieved via conversations.*
Content of messages and files accessed via the Web API
method_steps.notes: This is the core of the Cloud API execution: each API call is effectively a command being executed against the Slack tenant (for example, sending messages into exec channels, adding users to channels, or harvesting histories for later exfiltration).

method_steps.description: Optionally, register scheduled, event, or webhook-style triggers (for example, using Deno Slack SDK triggers or external schedulers) so that the app executes logic and Web API commands on a recurring or purely event-driven basis without active user interaction.
related_capabilities: Developer tools: Slack CLI, Bolt frameworks, SDKs, and sandboxes
related_interfaces: Deno Slack SDK triggers for schedules and webhooks as referenced in the workflows/apps comparison (https://docs.slack.dev/workflows/comparing-workflows-apps)
Webhook-initiated interactions described in the Interactivity docs (https://docs.slack.dev/interactivity/)
related_data: Trigger definitions (event types, schedules, webhook URLs)
Execution logs within the app backend indicating when automated tasks ran
method_steps.notes: This turns the Cloud API vector into persistent, low-touch execution: Slack events or external schedules continuously drive attacker-controlled code that issues Web API commands.

capabilities_used: Web API for core Slack operations
Interactivity: shortcuts, slash commands, and interactive components
App surfaces and Block Kit UI framework
OAuth-based authentication and tokens for apps
App distribution and Slack Marketplace listing
Developer tools: Slack CLI, Bolt frameworks, SDKs, and sandboxes
interfaces_used: Web API HTTP methods for Slack operations (https://docs.slack.dev/apis/web-api/)
Events API subscription and delivery endpoints (https://docs.slack.dev/apis/events-api/)
Interactivity endpoints for slash commands, shortcuts, and block_actions (https://docs.slack.dev/interactivity/)
Slack Marketplace app listing and install flows (https://slack.com/marketplace/)
Slack CLI and SDK tooling (https://docs.slack.dev/tools/, https://docs.slack.dev/tools/slack-cli/)
AI assistant thread events and methods for AI-enabled apps (https://docs.slack.dev/ai/developing-ai-apps)
data_accessed: OAuth access tokens (bot, user, app tokens) for the target workspace
App manifest and installation records (app_id, workspace_id, granted scopes)
Events API payloads containing message content and context (team_id, channel_id, user_id, ts)
Interactivity payloads from slash commands, shortcuts, and Block Kit components
Channel, DM, and thread identifiers and message_ts values
Message and file content retrieved or posted via Web API methods
Assistant thread context and AI-related metadata for AI-enabled apps
preconditions_required: A valid Slack workspace account or already-installed app in the target org with permission to install/configure apps.
Successfully obtaining OAuth tokens (bot/user/app) for an app in the target workspace—either via legitimate installation, supply-chain compromise of an existing app, or prior credential theft.
The workspace or org must allow apps with the required scopes (for example, chat:write, channels:history, users:read) to be installed; highly locked-down app governance may block new apps.

If the environment enforces SSO-only authentication and MFA for users, the attacker must already control an identity that can satisfy those flows or must already possess long-lived tokens that do not require interactive login.

If IP allowlisting is enforced around access to Slack’s APIs, the attacker’s app backend must be able to reach Slack endpoints from an allowlisted IP range (for example, by running from a compromised on-prem/allowed host).
constraints_encountered: MFA Required: makes it harder to obtain initial user credentials for installing or reconfiguring apps, but does not prevent use of already-issued OAuth tokens.
SSO-Only Authentication: restricts how user identities are obtained or abused to install apps; once tokens exist, API usage is unaffected.
Domain-Based Registration and Email Verification: limit the attacker’s ability to self-register accounts in the target org; they may need to compromise existing identities instead.
Admin Approval Required (for user registration): slows or prevents creation of new user accounts for installing apps, increasing reliance on compromising existing admins or users.

IP Allowlisting: if Slack access is restricted to specific IP ranges, the attacker’s app backend must operate from an allowlisted network segment or through a proxy/VPN, otherwise Web/API calls will be blocked.

Rate Limiting: Slack enforces API rate limits; aggressive automated use of chat.* and conversations.* methods will be throttled or temporarily blocked, forcing the attacker to adopt low-and-slow patterns.

App governance and approval workflows within Slack may require admin approval for app installs or restrict installs to Marketplace-reviewed apps, limiting the attacker’s ability to introduce a new custom app without detection.
evasion_considerations: Give the app a plausible, business-oriented name, icon, and description to reduce scrutiny during admin review and by end users.
Request the minimum visible set of scopes initially and expand them gradually or only where needed to avoid raising suspicion.
Design the app’s visible behavior to appear benign (for example, a helpful bot or notification tool) while hidden logic also collects or forwards data.
Throttle Web API calls to remain under rate limits and resemble normal app activity, avoiding bursts of large-scale historical reads or mass posting.
Prefer user-driven triggers (slash commands, message shortcuts) or limited event subscriptions so activity appears to be in response to real user actions.
Log minimally or store sensitive exfiltrated data off-Slack to avoid leaving obvious traces in app home views or Slack-managed artifacts.
vectors.comments: This is the primary execution vector for Slack: any custom app that holds OAuth tokens and receives Events/Interactivity payloads can execute arbitrary code on attacker-controlled infrastructure and then issue Web API commands as that app or user. For most orgs, the crown jewels in Slack are sensitive channels, DMs, and files (including exec/board channels and incident-response rooms). This vector lets an attacker continuously read from and write to those surfaces programmatically, enabling stealthy exfiltration or manipulation of communications.
vectors.execution_result: Programmatic execution of attacker-controlled code off-platform, with the ability to execute Slack Web/API commands (posting/streaming messages, reading channel history, modifying channels and memberships) across the target workspace using Cloud API tokens.
