preconditions_required: The target organization must be on a plan that exposes Admin, SCIM, Audit Logs, Legal Holds, and Oversight APIs (Business+ or Enterprise tiers as documented).
One or more OAuth tokens or SCIM credentials with elevated scopes (admin.*, SCIM access, auditlog:read, legalholds:* etc.) must be compromised or controlled by the attacker.
Org Owner/Admin approval is required to grant these scopes to any app; the attacker must already control an approved admin integration or a compromised admin account.
If SSO-only authentication and MFA are enforced, the attacker must have previously compromised the IdP or specific admin identities to obtain these privileged tokens.

Network/IP allowlisting around admin tooling or CI/CD must either permit the attacker’s automation environment or be bypassed (for example, by running from within the victim’s own CI/CD infrastructure).
constraints_encountered: MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication significantly increase the difficulty of compromising admin identities needed to acquire privileged API tokens.
Domain-Based Registration and Admin Approval for user registration make it harder for an attacker to create fresh admin-looking accounts inside the org.

IP Allowlisting may restrict which networks can reach Slack APIs or related IdP/SCIM endpoints; privileged automation often runs from known corporate IP ranges, which the attacker must access or spoof.
Rate Limiting applies to admin and SCIM endpoints as well; large bursts of user or channel changes or high-volume Audit Logs pulls may trigger throttling or operational alerts.

Internal governance policies around Admin and SCIM integrations may limit which apps are allowed to hold admin-level scopes, shrinking the available attack surface to a small set of high-value integrations.
evasion_considerations: Blend administrative API usage into existing maintenance patterns (for example, running jobs during routine maintenance windows, or matching existing SCIM sync schedules).
Throttle SCIM and Admin changes to avoid obvious spikes in provisioning/deprovisioning or role changes.
Use descriptive, plausible names for admin integrations and avoid requesting unnecessary scopes that would draw scrutiny from security reviewers.
Limit Audit Logs and Oversight pulls to targeted time ranges, users, or channels to look like focused investigations rather than bulk scraping.
Use legal holds and exports sparingly and in patterns that resemble legitimate legal or compliance activity for the organization.
vectors.comments: This vector is particularly dangerous because it moves beyond acting as a single user or bot and instead uses Slack’s Cloud APIs as a programmable org-level control plane. Once achieved, an attacker can quietly alter who is an admin, which channels exist and who is in them, what apps are approved, and which messages and files are preserved and exported—directly targeting an org’s most sensitive communications and governance data.
vectors.execution_result: Programmatic execution of highly privileged administrative, identity-management, logging, and legal-hold commands via Slack’s Admin, SCIM, Audit Logs, Oversight, and Legal Holds Cloud APIs, enabling organization-wide manipulation and access to Slack data.

preconditions_required: The target workspace or org must allow Slack-hosted apps built with the Deno Slack SDK and be on a plan that supports them (paid plan or developer sandbox, per the comparison tables).
An attacker-controlled developer identity (or compromised developer account) that can create and deploy Deno Slack SDK apps via the Slack CLI.
Admin or app-approval consent for installing the Slack-hosted app into the target workspace, depending on app governance settings.
Sufficient OAuth scopes granted to the app (for example, chat:write, channels:history) to let its functions access and act on the intended data.

If IP allowlisting or EMM policies restrict where Slack can be accessed from, the attacker must be able to perform CLI-based deployment from a compliant environment; runtime execution itself happens in Slack’s cloud.
constraints_encountered: Plan requirements: Deno Slack SDK apps and Slack-hosted workflows are not available on all plans; they require a paid plan or a developer sandbox, limiting where this vector exists.
App governance and admin approval may block new Slack-hosted apps from being installed broadly, especially in tightly controlled Enterprise orgs.
Rate Limiting still applies to Web API calls made from within the Deno functions; excessive automated access to messages or channels may be throttled.
MFA and SSO-only controls make it harder to compromise the developer or admin identities needed to configure and deploy Slack-hosted apps in the first place.
evasion_considerations: Position the Deno app as a legitimate automation or reporting tool to justify its presence as a Slack-hosted app.
Scope triggers narrowly (for example, specific channels or events) to reduce noisy or suspicious automated behavior across the org.
Throttle or batch Web API usage in the functions to stay under rate limits and resemble typical automation workloads.
Use Slack-hosted datastores and minimal external network calls to avoid creating obvious external exfiltration patterns that defenders could monitor.
Limit the app’s surface in the UI (for example, minimal or benign App Home content) so that non-technical users are less likely to question its behavior.
vectors.comments: This vector mirrors the MITRE ‘Serverless Execution’ technique: instead of AWS Lambda, the attacker abuses Slack’s Deno-based function hosting to run arbitrary code whenever Slack events, schedules, or webhooks fire. For crown jewels like executive channels and sensitive project spaces, a Slack-hosted app can quietly monitor and act on messages without any attacker-operated infrastructure, making detection harder if defenders focus mainly on external IP-based threats.
vectors.execution_result: Arbitrary attacker-defined code executes inside Slack’s managed Deno serverless environment in response to configured triggers, with the ability to call Slack Web APIs and, where permitted, external services, thereby automating actions over Slack data without external infrastructure.

preconditions_required: The target workspace must be on a plan that supports Workflow Builder (paid plan or equivalent) and have Workflow Builder enabled.
The attacker must control a user account with permission to create and manage workflows in the relevant workspace and channels.

Connector apps leveraged by the workflow must already be installed and authorized with appropriate scopes, or the attacker must have rights to install/configure them (subject to app governance and admin approvals).
If SSO-only and MFA are enforced, the attacker must have already compromised a legitimate user account that can access Workflow Builder.
Slack Connect policies and channel permissions must allow the attacker-controlled account to attach workflows to the target channels where sensitive data flows.
constraints_encountered: Plan and feature availability: Workflow Builder is only available on paid plans or developer sandboxes; free workspaces are excluded.
Workflow permissions and governance may restrict who can create workflows or which connectors they can use, limiting the attacker to what is allowed for their role.
App governance and approval workflows may restrict which connector apps are available inside Workflow Builder, reducing the set of third-party services that can be reached.
Rate Limiting and internal safeguards can limit how frequently workflows run or how many API calls connector-backed steps can generate, forcing the attacker to avoid overly aggressive schedules.

MFA, SSO-only authentication, domain-based registration, and admin approval for new users all raise the bar to obtaining the authoring account needed to build or edit workflows but do not directly constrain workflow execution once configured.
evasion_considerations: Name workflows and descriptions to match common business processes (for example, “Customer escalation triage” or “Weekly project digest”) to avoid scrutiny by admins and users.
Attach workflows to channels where automation is already expected (operations, support, CRM-integration channels) so new automated posts do not stand out.
Use moderate schedules (hourly/daily) instead of very frequent triggers to keep activity low and within normal operational patterns.
Leverage existing connectors that the organization already relies on rather than introducing new, suspicious integrations.

Avoid creating workflows that obviously move data to visibly external or attacker-controlled destinations; instead, pivot data into intermediate locations or other SaaS systems that defenders perceive as trusted.
vectors.comments: This vector aligns with MITRE’s treatment of SaaS automation platforms like Power Automate or Apps Script: Slack’s Workflow Builder provides a serverless, no-code way to run attacker-chosen logic—in this case, orchestrated steps and connectors—whenever events, schedules, or webhooks fire. For Slack, the crown jewels are often concentrated in key channels and project canvases/lists; a malicious workflow can continuously capture, transform, or route that information to places the attacker controls or can later access, all while appearing as routine automation.
vectors.execution_result: Automated, serverless execution of attacker-defined workflows inside Slack whenever configured triggers fire, performing actions on Slack data and integrated third-party services without additional attacker infrastructure or direct user interaction.

execution.summary:
Within Slack, realistic execution vectors map to two MITRE SaaS Execution techniques: Cloud API and Serverless Execution.

1) Cloud API (standard app tokens): By controlling or compromising a Slack app that holds OAuth tokens, an adversary can run arbitrary code on their own infrastructure in response to Events API and Interactivity payloads, then issue Web API commands (chat.*, conversations.*, streaming, assistant.*) against the workspace. This enables automated posting, reading, and manipulation of channels/DMs and is the primary way to programmatically drive Slack’s core surfaces.

2) Cloud API (privileged Admin/SCIM/Audit/Legal Holds APIs): With admin-level tokens or SCIM credentials, the same Cloud API pattern extends to high-privilege operations. Attackers can execute scripted org-wide commands to manage users, channels, workflows, and app approvals, pull Audit Logs and oversight-visible content, and manipulate legal holds and exports. This turns Slack’s administrative plane into a programmable control surface over the organization’s communications and governance data.

3) Serverless Execution via Slack-hosted Deno Slack SDK apps: Slack-hosted Deno apps run attacker-defined functions in Slack’s managed runtime when triggers (events, schedules, webhooks, slash commands) fire. This mirrors malicious Lambda-style serverless execution, with Slack executing Deno code that can call Web APIs and external services without the attacker running any servers.

4) Serverless Execution via Workflow Builder and connectors: Workflow Builder acts as a no-code serverless environment. An attacker with workflow-author permissions can define event- or schedule-triggered workflows that automatically perform Slack actions and call third-party connectors. Once enabled, these workflows run inside Slack’s automation engine, continuously manipulating or routing data with no further attacker presence required.

Environment-level constraints (MFA, SSO-only auth, domain-based registration, admin approval for users, IP allowlisting, and rate limiting) primarily raise the bar for obtaining the identities and app/workflow authoring rights used in these vectors. They do not prevent execution once a valid app token, admin token, or workflow configuration exists. Consequently, the most critical defenses for Slack execution risk are tight app governance and review, strict control of admin and SCIM integrations, and strong oversight of Workflow Builder usage and Slack-hosted apps, especially in channels and workspaces containing executive and highly sensitive communications.

preconditions_required: Attacker controls an app’s backend and credentials (for a new malicious app) or has compromised an existing app/agent that is or can be installed in the target Slack environment.
A compromised Slack user account with permission to install apps, or a compromised Workspace/Org Admin who can both approve and install apps.
App installation is not wholly blocked by restrictive app-governance policies, or the attacker also controls app-approval automation or approvers.
For admin.*, Audit Logs, Oversight, or Legal Holds access, the attacker must have an admin grant those high-privilege scopes to the app.
constraints_encountered: Admin Approval Required: if the org enforces admin approval for all apps, the attacker must already control an approver or subvert the approval workflow.

MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication: increase the difficulty of initially compromising the admin/user account needed to install the app, but do not constrain subsequent use of the app’s OAuth tokens once issued.
IP Allowlisting: may restrict interactive admin access to the Slack admin console; the attacker may need to operate from an allowlisted endpoint to complete installation or scope changes.
Rate Limiting: Slack’s Web API rate limits require the attacker’s app to pace API calls to avoid throttling and obvious abuse patterns.
evasion_considerations: Name and brand the app as a plausible internal tool (e.g., “Compliance Sync” or “Workflow Helper”) and keep visible posting behavior minimal.
Request only the minimum initial scopes needed, then append additional scopes later once the app has built trust or when defenders are distracted.
Use Socket Mode or a limited set of Events API subscriptions to avoid appearing overly broad in app configuration and admin reviews.
Throttle Web API calls and avoid large-scale history pulls that could stand out in Audit Logs or SIEM telemetry.
Where possible, deploy the app as an internal (undistributed) app so it does not undergo Marketplace review and is harder for external parties to scrutinize.
vectors.comments: For Slack, Cloud Application Integration via OAuth apps and AI agents is arguably the highest-impact persistence mechanism: tokens are non-expiring by default, scopes are additive, and enterprise integrations (including admin, SCIM, Audit Logs, and Legal Holds apps) are explicitly designed to run continuously with high privilege.
vectors.persistence_mechanism: Long-lived OAuth tokens, event subscriptions, and assistant threads for a malicious or hijacked Slack app/AI agent that remains installed and authorized in the workspace/org, providing durable API- and event-level access to messages, files, admin APIs, and AI surfaces until the app is explicitly uninstalled or its tokens are revoked.

preconditions_required: A compromised Slack user or admin account that is allowed to create and publish workflows in the relevant workspace.
Workflow Builder must be enabled for the workspace, and (if applicable) workflow permissions must allow the compromised user to target the desired channels.
For workflows that use connectors or app steps, those apps/connectors must already be approved and installed, or the attacker must also be able to install/approve them.
constraints_encountered: Admin Approval Required: if admins tightly control who can create workflows or which connectors may be used, the attacker is limited to what the compromised account can access.
MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication: affect initial compromise of the account, but once the workflow is created and published, Slack runs it autonomously regardless of MFA.
Rate Limiting: high-frequency or heavy workflows may hit API or connector limits, potentially drawing attention via performance issues or logs.
evasion_considerations: Use low-frequency schedules (e.g., daily/weekly) and narrow event filters to avoid generating conspicuous volumes of automated activity.
Avoid obviously suspicious step descriptions; name workflows and steps to resemble legitimate reporting or notification automations.
Prefer exfiltration via existing, trusted connectors or apps rather than adding new, obviously attacker-controlled integrations.
Ensure workflow owners are accounts that defenders are unlikely to scrutinize closely (e.g., a generic team operations account rather than a high-profile executive).
vectors.comments: Slack’s Workflow Builder and event/schedule-driven automations provide a first-class, always-on execution environment inside the tenant. Once a malicious workflow is published, Slack’s own automation engine ensures persistent execution even if the original compromised user is inactive, making this a powerful and often-overlooked persistence path.
vectors.persistence_mechanism: One or more long-lived workflows and app-based event triggers that continue to execute automatically on schedules or in response to Slack events, performing attacker-chosen actions (including data collection or exfiltration) as long as the workflow definitions remain enabled.

preconditions_required: Compromise of a Workspace/Org Admin account or of credentials/API keys used by the organization’s SCIM/IdP integration with Slack.
Ability to satisfy SSO and MFA policies for the new account (either by controlling the IdP, registering MFA, or abusing misconfigurations).
If Domain-Based Registration and Email Verification are enforced for invites, the attacker must control or be able to create an email address in an allowed domain.
constraints_encountered: SSO-Only Authentication: if enforced, local Slack credentials cannot be used, and the new account must exist and be permitted in the IdP; otherwise SCIM may auto-deprovision it.
MFA Required: the attacker must complete MFA enrollment and token possession to gain interactive access to the new account.
Domain-Based Registration and Email Verification Required: for invite-based creation, the email must be on an approved domain and under attacker control.
Admin Approval Required: in some environments, new accounts or guest accounts may require additional approval flows that the attacker must be able to manipulate via compromised admins.
evasion_considerations: Choose an account name, email, and profile that match legitimate naming conventions for service or automation accounts in the organization.
Assign only the minimum roles that still allow persistence (e.g., workspace admin in a key workspace instead of org-wide owner) to avoid standing out.
Avoid logging in from suspicious IP ranges where IP allowlisting is enforced; instead, operate from compromised endpoints within the allowlist.
Let defenders discover and remediate more obviously compromised user accounts while the backdoor account remains dormant or low-activity.
vectors.comments: Slack’s reliance on SCIM and admin UIs for user lifecycle, combined with known SCIM misconfiguration failure modes, makes hidden or mis-scoped accounts a realistic persistence method. Once created and given the right memberships, such accounts can silently observe and act within key channels for long periods.
vectors.persistence_mechanism: One or more attacker-controlled Slack user identities (often disguised as service or automation accounts) that are provisioned via admin UI or SCIM, assigned to sensitive channels and possibly admin roles, and operated sparingly to maintain long-term access even after initial compromised accounts are remediated.

preconditions_required: Initial compromise of at least one high-privilege Slack account (Workspace/Org Admin or Owner) or a high-privilege admin app.
Sufficient privileges to change user roles, group memberships, and app scopes, either through the admin UI or Admin/SCIM APIs.
In organizations where SCIM drives roles, the attacker must also be able to influence SCIM group assignments or mappings, or operate within the constraints SCIM imposes.
constraints_encountered: SSO-Only Authentication and SCIM: if SCIM strictly enforces role mappings, local changes to roles may be reverted by the next SCIM sync unless the attacker also manipulates SCIM configuration.
MFA Required: increases difficulty of maintaining long-lived interactive sessions on elevated human accounts, but has limited effect on app tokens.
Audit and compliance monitoring: role changes, new admin apps, and scope grants are typically visible via the Audit Logs API and may be alerted upon.
evasion_considerations: Grant elevated roles to a small number of inconspicuous accounts that fit existing naming patterns (e.g., shared IT accounts or automation users).
Stage role changes over time and across different admin sessions to reduce the chance that a burst of IAM changes triggers alerts.
Where possible, drive elevation through SCIM group membership changes rather than direct Slack role changes, so that Slack appears to be faithfully following the directory of record.
Ensure admin-focused apps have business-plausible descriptions and scope sets (e.g., “SCIM Sync Service” or “Audit Exporter”) to avoid immediate scrutiny.
vectors.comments: By expanding the set of privileged identities—both human and application—under attacker control, the adversary ensures that revoking or cleaning up one account is insufficient to remove their access. This mirrors observed cloud campaigns where multiple service principals and user accounts are granted high-level roles for resilience.
vectors.persistence_mechanism: Multiple low-profile user accounts and admin-focused apps that have been silently granted Workspace/Org admin roles and powerful scopes, providing redundant, high-privilege access paths that persist even if the originally compromised admin account is detected and remediated.

constraints_encountered: MFA Required: constrains ongoing interactive use of compromised human accounts; once OAuth tokens or app integrations are in place, API usage is no longer gated by MFA.

vectors.comments: This vector represents the classic use of valid cloud accounts for persistence: continuing to operate using existing Slack users, external Slack Connect identities, and long-lived integration tokens. vectors.persistence_mechanism: Ongoing use of compromised Slack cloud accounts and integration tokens—including internal admins, service accounts, external Slack Connect users, and admin integrations—to access messages, files, admin APIs, and cross-tenant channels over time, relying on the fact that these identities and tokens persist until explicitly deprovisioned or revoked.

persistence.summary:
Slack’s design as a programmable collaboration hub exposes multiple, realistic persistence mechanisms for an attacker who has already obtained some level of access:

- **Malicious or hijacked apps/AI agents (Cloud Application Integration)** can be installed once and granted broad, often admin-level scopes. Slack’s OAuth tokens do not expire by default and scopes are additive, so a compromised app’s bot/admin tokens plus Events API subscriptions provide long-lived, low-friction access to messages, files, and admin APIs until the app is explicitly uninstalled or tokens are revoked.

- **Persistent workflows and event-triggered automations (Event Triggered Execution)** created via Workflow Builder or app-based triggers will run indefinitely on schedules or in response to events, even if the originating user is inactive. These workflows can quietly monitor sensitive channels and feed data to attacker-controlled destinations via existing connectors or apps.

- **Covert Slack accounts (Create Account)** can be created via the admin UI or SCIM and then added to sensitive channels and admin groups. When disguised as service or automation users and operated sparingly, such accounts provide durable, interactive access, especially in environments where SCIM misconfiguration leaves lingering or over-privileged users.

- **Expanded admin roles and admin integrations (Additional Cloud Roles)** allow an attacker to silently grant Workspace/Org admin privileges to low-profile accounts and admin-focused apps. These elevated identities can manage users, channels, workflows, app approvals, and Slack Connect, ensuring that even if one admin is remediated, others under attacker control can re-establish or maintain access.

- **Continued use of compromised Slack cloud accounts and tokens (Cloud Accounts)**—including internal users/admins, third-party admin integrations, and external Slack Connect users—gives attackers a straightforward persistence path. Non-expiring OAuth tokens and durable Slack Connect shared channels mean that, without explicit revocation or deprovisioning, these accounts can continue accessing internal conversations and admin interfaces over long periods.

Environmental constraints like **MFA, SSO-only auth, domain-based registration, IP allowlisting, rate limiting, and admin approvals** primarily raise the bar for initial compromise and interactive use of human accounts. They do far less to constrain persistence mechanisms that rely on:

- non-expiring OAuth tokens for apps and admin integrations,
- Slack’s own automation engine (workflows and triggers), and
- cross-tenant Slack Connect relationships.

Effective mitigation therefore requires not only strong identity controls but also tight app governance, regular audits of workflows and admin roles, continuous monitoring of Audit Logs/API usage, and periodic reviews of Slack Connect relationships and high-privilege integrations.

constraints_encountered: MFA Required: An attacker must compromise MFA or bypass it at the IdP to authenticate as the escalated admin account.
SSO-Only Authentication: Slack does not allow local passwords when SSO-only is enforced, so the attacker must target the IdP or SAML tokens, not Slack-native credentials.

Domain-Based Registration and Admin Approval Required: New SCIM-provisioned users must typically use approved domains and may be subject to admin-side review, limiting ability to create obviously suspicious accounts.
IP Allowlisting: If enforced, SCIM operations and subsequent admin UI/API access must originate from allowed IP ranges, pushing attackers to pivot through existing infrastructure.
Rate Limiting and Logging: High-volume or anomalous SCIM and Admin API activity can be throttled or flagged in Audit Logs and customer SIEMs.
evasion_considerations: Modify only a small number of SCIM users/groups and mirror existing naming conventions to avoid obvious anomalies in admin or group listings.
Perform SCIM changes and admin role assignments during normal change windows or alongside legitimate provisioning changes.
Use a single attacker-controlled account added to an existing admin group instead of creating many new admins, reducing the number of suspicious events.
After establishing backup admin identities and app tokens, reduce further SCIM/admin activity to minimize additional logging noise.
vectors.comments: This vector directly targets Slack’s identity and provisioning plane. Once the attacker has an admin/owner role, they can reach Slack’s crown jewels: organization-wide message history (including private channels and DMs via discovery/oversight tools), file repositories, legal-hold and export mechanisms, and security/audit logs. The main risk driver is that SCIM and IdP misconfiguration or compromise can silently grant admin rights inside Slack via normal provisioning flows.
vectors.escalated_access: One or more attacker-controlled Slack user accounts are assigned Workspace/Org Admin or Owner roles, giving full control of workspace/org configuration, app approvals, and the ability to drive data exports, legal holds, and broad channel/DM visibility.

preconditions_required: Attacker can register or control a Slack app (internally or as a third-party) that the target workspace will consider for installation.
The target organization permits installation of internal or Marketplace apps, and at least one admin or end user is willing (or can be socially engineered) to install the initial low-privilege app.

constraints_encountered: Admin Approval Required (for apps and high-priv scopes in practice): strong app approval processes will limit the feasibility of acquiring admin.*, Audit Logs, Legal Holds, or SCIM scopes.
MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication reduce direct account theft but do not prevent over-scoped OAuth grants; however admins will need to authenticate with MFA to approve scopes.
Rate Limiting applies to Admin and SCIM APIs; large-scale abuse of new credentials may be throttled or detected.
CAPTCHA Protection and Email Verification Required are largely irrelevant to OAuth installs themselves but may affect any supporting web flows the attacker uses for social engineering.
Extensive use of the privileged token is visible via the Audit Logs API and internal logging, so noisy operations may trigger detections.
evasion_considerations: Introduce elevated scopes gradually and tie them to plausible new features (e.g., “workspace analytics” or “admin reporting”) to justify admin.* or Audit Logs access.
Limit high-privilege API calls in volume and timing, blending them with normal app behavior and staying within typical rate and usage patterns.
Name the app and its scopes to resemble existing trusted tools or vendor names, lowering the chance that admins question expanded permissions.
Prefer indirect data access via admin APIs and oversight mechanisms rather than immediately exporting entire histories, to avoid large, obvious spikes in audit and export activity.
vectors.comments: This vector turns an app into an adversary-controlled cloud identity with high-privilege Slack access. The resulting tokens can be used to read sensitive content (including private channels and DMs via oversight tools), manipulate users and channels, and manage legal holds and exports. In many Slack-heavy organizations, these admin-focused apps and connectors are key crown-jewel access paths because they centralize broad visibility and control into a single OAuth credential.
vectors.escalated_access: High-privilege OAuth tokens for a malicious or compromised Slack app, granting access to admin.*, SCIM, Audit Logs, Legal Holds, and other sensitive APIs well beyond any single end user’s original permissions.

In many Slack-heavy organizations, private channels (executive, legal, incident-response, customer escalations) and oversight/export interfaces are core crown jewels; by silently adding attacker-controlled identities into those spaces, an adversary gains strategic visibility without necessarily announcing themselves as an admin.

preconditions_required: Attacker has admin rights (or equivalent app-owner rights) to modify privileged workflows or admin apps in the target Slack organization.
Automation exists (or can be created) that runs with higher privileges than a typical end user (e.g., admin-scoped app tokens).
The attacker can authenticate to Slack and access Workflow Builder / app deployment tooling, satisfying MFA, SSO, and IP Allowlisting constraints.

constraints_encountered: MFA Required, SSO-Only Authentication, and IP Allowlisting restrict who can modify workflows and admin apps, pushing attackers toward already-compromised high-priv identities.
Audit Logs capture configuration changes and potentially workflow runs, so suspicious additions of admin steps can be investigated after-the-fact.
Rate Limiting on admin and SCIM APIs may limit high-frequency abuse from automated workflows, though single-shot role or membership changes typically remain feasible.
Workflow governance policies may limit who is allowed to create or edit workflows that touch admin-governed resources.
evasion_considerations: Embed malicious logic as a small addition to an existing, legitimate automation (such as an onboarding or reporting workflow) rather than creating a new, obviously suspicious workflow.
Trigger the workflow using normal business events or schedules instead of ad-hoc test triggers, making execution patterns appear routine.
Revert or minimize visible changes to workflow/app configuration after successful privilege escalation while retaining persistent effects (e.g., new admin accounts or app tokens).
Restrict the automation to operate on a narrow set of accounts (only the attacker-controlled identities) to reduce anomalous bulk operations.
vectors.comments: This vector abuses Slack’s automation stack—Workflow Builder, event-based app triggers, and AI agents—as a conduit for executing admin-level operations in response to normal events. Once an attacker controls such automation, they can use it to quietly add themselves to admin roles, sensitive channels, or approve new privileged apps. For organizations heavily invested in automated onboarding, channel management, or AI helpers, these workflows and agents become critical crown-jewel pathways because they act as always-on cloud operators with concentrated privileges.
vectors.escalated_access: Attacker-controlled workflows or agents that, when triggered by events or schedules, execute admin-level Admin/SCIM operations, resulting in elevated roles or expanded channel/app permissions for attacker identities.

preconditions_required: Attacker has already obtained valid credentials, access tokens, or long-lived sessions for a high-privilege Slack cloud account (e.g., via phishing, IdP compromise, or token theft in another environment).
The compromised account actually holds Org/Workspace Admin or Owner permissions in Slack.
The attacker can satisfy MFA and SSO requirements for the account and reach Slack from an IP range allowed by any IP Allowlisting policies.
The organization has enabled admin-focused features (data exports, oversight APIs, legal holds) for the compromised account’s role.
constraints_encountered: MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication significantly increase the difficulty of obtaining the admin account initially; successful exploitation typically requires upstream IdP or MFA compromise.
IP Allowlisting forces attackers to operate from or through trusted network ranges, increasing the risk and complexity of access.
Audit Logs record admin logins, configuration changes, app approvals, data exports, and other high-impact actions, providing a strong detection surface for security teams.
Rate Limiting on Admin and export APIs can slow large-scale data theft but does not prevent targeted operations.
evasion_considerations: Use the compromised admin account only during typical working hours and from network locations that resemble the legitimate user’s normal patterns (e.g., corporate VPN endpoints).
Mimic legitimate admin behavior—such as routine app approvals or configuration tweaks—while piggybacking malicious actions in small increments.
Prefer creating one or two well-camouflaged backup admin identities and privileged apps rather than continuously operating from the originally compromised account.
Throttle data export and oversight queries to avoid sudden spikes that may stand out in SIEMs or audit dashboards.
vectors.comments: Here, the Slack admin/owner account itself is the cloud account being abused. Slack’s role in privilege escalation is to honor whatever level of access the compromised cloud identity has: once inside, the attacker can spawn additional admin identities, apps, and tokens, then pull from crown-jewel surfaces such as exports, legal holds, audit logs, and EKM-governed content. This mirrors real-world campaigns against other SaaS platforms where a single compromised global admin account yields organization-wide access.
vectors.escalated_access: Interactive and API-level access as a Slack Org/Workspace Admin or Owner, plus any additional privileged identities and app tokens created from that foothold, enabling organization-wide administration and data access.

constraints_encountered: Slack workspaces and Enterprise organizations are created with standard user identities managed via email/SSO and do not expose vendor-set default admin credentials for customers to use.
Authentication and access control are tied to customer-managed identity providers (SSO/SCIM) and Slack-managed user accounts; any ‘root’ or Slack-internal accounts are not accessible to tenants.
Default bot identities such as Slackbot are not authenticatable cloud accounts with passwords or tokens that customers can log in as.
vectors.comments: MITRE’s Default Accounts technique relies on factory-set or provider-set credentials (for example, default admin/guest accounts on appliances, root users in cloud consoles, or preset service accounts). In the documented Slack model, tenant-level administration is done through customer-managed identities (via SSO and SCIM) and Slack-managed user accounts; there is no evidence of customer-accessible default admin accounts with known or static passwords. Slackbot and similar built-in actors are not authenticatable accounts. As a result, there is no realistic privilege escalation vector in Slack that hinges on abusing default credentials alone; attackers must instead compromise normal accounts, SCIM integrations, or app tokens as described in the other vectors.

privilege_escalation.summary:
Slack’s privilege-escalation surface is dominated by its identity and administration layers rather than low-level exploits. The most powerful vectors all revolve around:

- **Role and group management via SCIM and Admin APIs (Additional Cloud Roles)** – If an attacker controls SCIM credentials or admin.* tokens, they can assign Workspace/Org Admin or Owner roles to attacker-controlled users, converting low-priv identities into full administrators. This in turn unlocks exports, legal holds, oversight APIs, and org-wide configuration control.

- **Over-scoped or escalated OAuth tokens for apps (Additional Cloud Credentials)** – By evolving a seemingly-benign internal or Marketplace app into one with admin.*, SCIM, Audit Logs, and Legal Holds scopes, an attacker can turn that app into an additional privileged cloud credential. These tokens often outlive any one human user and give broad, API-driven access to Slack crown jewels.

- **Manipulating memberships and account attributes (Account Manipulation)** – Once some admin capability is obtained, quietly adding attacker-controlled accounts into high-value private channels, adjusting account types, and weakening Slack Connect restrictions creates practical privilege escalation: direct access to executive, legal, and incident-response conversations and files without necessarily changing visible ‘admin’ labels.

- **Abusing privileged automation (Event Triggered Execution)** – High-priv workflows, admin apps, and AI agents can be modified so that, when triggered by normal events or schedules, they execute admin.* or SCIM operations on the attacker’s behalf. These event-driven paths can auto-add admins, approve apps, or adjust memberships, making them potent but subtle escalation channels.

- **Use of compromised admin cloud accounts (Cloud Accounts)** – A stolen Org/Workspace Admin or Owner identity acts as a master key: once authenticated through SSO+MFA, it can create more admins, approve privileged apps, and orchestrate exports, legal holds, and oversight queries. Slack’s own capabilities faithfully enforce whatever this cloud account is allowed to do.

Environment constraints like **MFA, SSO-only authentication, domain-based registration, admin approval for new accounts/apps, IP allowlisting, and rate limiting** raise the bar for obtaining the necessary tokens and identities, but they do not prevent escalation once those credentials are compromised or over-granted. Slack’s true crown jewels—complete message and file history (including private channels and DMs via oversight/export), audit logs, legal-hold preserved content, and control over encryption access via EKM—are all directly reachable once an attacker has succeeded with any of the viable vectors above.

preconditions_required: Attacker controls or has hijacked an Org Owner/Org Admin or Workspace Owner/Admin account, OR possesses an app token with admin.* and auditlog scopes.
Environment may enforce SSO-only authentication and MFA for admins; the attacker must already have satisfied or bypassed these controls to obtain admin-equivalent access.
Any Slack-to-SIEM or monitoring integrations must be implemented using apps or export tooling that can be uninstalled, restricted, or reconfigured via the documented admin interfaces.
constraints_encountered: MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication significantly raise the bar for compromising admin accounts, but do not restrict what a legitimately authenticated admin can do to app approvals or Audit Logs API consumers.
IP Allowlisting can limit where admins can connect from; the attacker must operate from an allowlisted IP (for example via VPN or a compromised internal host).
Rate Limiting on APIs means an attacker must avoid obviously abusive Audit Logs API or admin.* usage while probing and modifying integrations.
Admin Approval Required for new user registrations does not directly hinder this vector because it relies on already-compromised privileged identities.
evasion_considerations: Stage changes gradually and align them with plausible maintenance activities (for example, “rotating SIEM integration keys” or “replacing legacy monitoring app”) so audit entries about app removals and token revocation look routine.

Avoid fully removing all monitoring; instead, degrade coverage (for example, forwarding only a subset of events) so defenders still see some benign activity from Slack and may not immediately notice missing categories.
Maintain at least one apparent monitoring or export app in an approved state to satisfy governance reviews that simply check for the existence of audit integrations.
Combine with other vectors (for example, shortened retention or key revocation) so that by the time defenders realize logging has been impaired, underlying evidence is already unavailable.
vectors.comments: This vector closely parallels documented cloud attacks where adversaries disable or reconfigure AWS CloudTrail or Microsoft 365 Purview Audit. In Slack, the realistic lever is not turning off Slack’s internal logging, but breaking or subverting the organization’s visibility via the Audit Logs API and export-based monitoring.
vectors.evasion_achieved: Customer-side audit logging and SIEM-based monitoring of Slack are impaired or selectively blinded, so malicious admin and app actions still occur but are no longer fully visible in the organization’s primary detection systems.

MFA and SSO controls on admin accounts have already been satisfied or bypassed as part of an earlier phase.
The organization relies on Slack’s message and file history as key evidence in investigations, rather than exclusively on out-of-band archival or journaling systems.
constraints_encountered: MFA Required, SSO-Only Authentication, and IP Allowlisting constrain who can access admin retention and legal hold settings but do not limit what a legitimately authenticated admin can configure.
Admin Approval Required and Domain-Based Registration for new users make it harder to open disposable workspaces or accounts, but do not prevent manipulating retention on existing workspaces.
Rate Limiting is largely irrelevant for one-time configuration changes, though overly aggressive automation of retention tweaks via APIs could stand out.
evasion_considerations: Apply retention changes narrowly (for example, to a small set of channels or a ‘project’ workspace) and justify them as compliance or privacy improvements to reduce scrutiny of policy changes in audit logs.
Avoid frequent toggling of policies; instead, set aggressive retention before malicious activity and leave it in place so configuration churn does not itself become a detection signal.
Ensure that any legal or regulatory obligations are superficially met elsewhere (for example, by claiming exports or external archives exist) to discourage deep review of Slack’s internal history.
Combine with log/monitoring impairment and, where available, EKM key revocation so that even Slack-side backups and preserved data are difficult to read during incident response.
vectors.comments: Here, retention, legal holds, and search visibility are treated as part of the effective ‘logging and evidence’ plane for Slack conversations. Misconfiguring them can functionally remove or hide traces of attacker activity without needing per-message deletion.
vectors.evasion_achieved: Message and file content relevant to malicious actions is automatically and legitimately purged or made undiscoverable under configured policies, sharply limiting what investigators can review even though Slack itself continues to operate normally.

preconditions_required: Enterprise+ plan with Enterprise Key Management enabled for the relevant Slack organization.
Attacker has compromised AWS IAM roles with administrative control over the KMS keys used by Slack EKM and, ideally, access to CloudWatch/CloudTrail for those keys.
Attacker also has sufficient Slack admin or investigation visibility to identify which scopes (workspaces, channels, timeframes) contain incriminating content.
constraints_encountered: MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication may protect both Slack admin accounts and AWS IAM identities; this vector assumes those protections have already been bypassed.
IP Allowlisting could restrict where AWS and Slack admin sessions originate; the attacker must operate from allowed ranges or via compromised internal systems.
Rate Limiting is not a major constraint because EKM revocation and AWS log changes are low-frequency configuration actions.
evasion_considerations: Limit revocation to the smallest feasible scope (for example, a narrow timeframe for a specific channel) to minimize user-visible disruption and reduce the chance that unusual ‘content unavailable due to key management’ errors draw attention.
Align revocation with legitimate key rotation or compliance activities so that KMS and Slack audit records seem consistent with expected security operations.
If possible, retain partial access for high-profile channels to avoid widespread user complaints that would trigger investigation outside normal logging workflows.
Combine with log/monitoring impairment so that defenders lose both plaintext content and easy visibility into the key changes that caused its loss.
vectors.comments: Although EKM is primarily a confidentiality and compliance feature, misuse of customer-controlled keys and their logs can have a defense evasion effect by rendering targeted Slack content undecryptable to investigators while leaving the rest of the service functioning.
vectors.evasion_achieved: Selected Slack messages and files become permanently unreadable due to targeted EKM key revocation, preventing investigators from viewing the underlying content even if they still have access to audit metadata and governance APIs.

preconditions_required: Attacker can either publish an app and have it installed in the target Slack org or compromise the backend/tokens of an existing approved app.
App must be granted sufficient OAuth scopes by an admin or user (for example, to read messages/files or call admin APIs).
Any app-approval and Marketplace-only restrictions in the organization must be weak, misconfigured, or bypassed (for example, via social engineering of an admin).
constraints_encountered: MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication apply at install/consent time, making it harder to trick admins into authorizing the app, but do not constrain subsequent API use of already-issued tokens.
IP Allowlisting typically applies to user interactive access; most Slack apps legitimately call APIs from external infrastructure, so API calls from the attacker’s servers can blend in.
Rate Limiting on Web API and Events API requires the attacker to keep data collection and actions within normal bounds or to distribute activity across multiple workspaces/tokens.
Admin Approval Required for app installation may require the attacker to either compromise an admin or hijack an already-approved internal app.
evasion_considerations: Design the app to provide real value (for example, useful notifications or AI assistance) so defenders and users have a reason to keep it installed, masking its hidden behavior.
Throttle data collection and administrative actions to match expected integration patterns rather than aggressively scraping entire histories at once.
Re-use existing app identities and names where possible (or see the “Masquerade Account Name” vector) so activity appears to come from trusted tooling rather than a new, suspicious bot.
Prefer API-based access via tokens over logging in as users; this avoids many user-facing alerts, reduces MFA prompts, and concentrates visibility into less-scrutinized app logs.
vectors.comments: This vector mirrors numerous real-world campaigns in which adversaries abuse OAuth-based access tokens for cloud mail and file services to maintain long-term, low-noise access. In Slack, malicious or compromised apps and AI agents play the same role.
vectors.evasion_achieved: The attacker operates primarily through legitimate-looking Slack apps and AI agents using long-lived OAuth access tokens, bypassing MFA, SSO, and many user-centric detections while blending into normal integration traffic.

The environment uses Slack integrated with corporate SSO/SCIM so that new or repurposed accounts can be added without raising obvious out-of-band registration alerts.

constraints_encountered: Domain-Based Registration and Admin Approval Required for new accounts hinder mass self-service signups but are moot if the attacker already controls SCIM or admin workflows.

MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication also apply to these accounts, but they look like every other managed cloud identity; attackers can use phishing or IdP abuse to obtain their tokens like any other.
IP Allowlisting may limit where these accounts can sign in from; attackers may need to route access through allowed corporate networks or existing cloud infrastructure used by legitimate automations.
evasion_considerations: Name and describe accounts in ways that match existing naming conventions for service and automation users (for example, ‘hr-reporting-bot’) so they blend into identity inventories.
Keep activity volumes and patterns similar to expected background automation—occasional reads and writes, scheduled operations—rather than highly interactive behavior.
Leverage SCIM to ensure these accounts are not accidentally deprovisioned when targeted employees leave, turning them into durable footholds.
If incident responders disable a subset of user accounts after a breach, continue operations through other pre-positioned cloud accounts created earlier to maintain redundant access.
vectors.comments: This vector treats Slack user identities as cloud accounts in the MITRE sense, with SCIM and SSO serving as the provisioning plane. Service-style Slack users become the equivalent of stealthy service principals used in other SaaS compromises.
vectors.evasion_achieved: Malicious activity is funneled through legitimate-looking Slack cloud accounts that resemble background services or back-office users, making it harder for defenders to distinguish attacker actions from normal automation or low-profile usage.

constraints_encountered: Domain-Based Registration and Admin Approval Required reduce the chance of arbitrary self-service signups, pushing the attacker toward repurposing existing accounts or working through SCIM/IdP control.
MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication protect account sign-in but do not prevent renaming or rebranding identities once compromised.

evasion_considerations: Align names, email-style handles, and avatars exactly with internal conventions (for example, mirroring known backup or monitoring tools) so they appear in line with existing assets.
Avoid giving these accounts overtly high privileges (for example, global admin) unless the environment already uses similarly privileged service accounts.
Ensure that at least some visible behavior from these accounts matches their purported role (for example, sending benign system notifications) to reinforce the illusion.
When defenders later query audit logs, ensure that sensitive admin actions are intermixed with routine-seeming events from the same masqueraded identity.
vectors.comments: This vector extends the idea of ‘Masquerade Account Name’ from operating systems into Slack’s identity and app layers, leveraging realistic-looking user, bot, and agent names to reduce suspicion around otherwise anomalous actions.
vectors.evasion_achieved: Suspicious administrative and data-access actions appear in UI and audit logs as being performed by accounts that look like legitimate system, support, or backup identities, making it less likely that human reviewers or ad hoc audits flag them.

preconditions_required: Attacker has compromised or can create Slack identities that users will accept as legitimate representatives of IT, security, HR, or leadership.
Admins and staff materially rely on Slack for operational coordination and approval workflows, so that decisions can be influenced via Slack messages.
Defensive processes do not require strong out-of-band verification for high-impact approvals (for example, disabling logging, relaxing retention, or installing powerful apps).
constraints_encountered: MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication increase effort to compromise high-value identities, but once compromised, they confer strong trust within Slack.
Rate Limiting and CAPTCHA are not significant constraints because this vector relies on low-volume, highly targeted social interactions rather than automated abuse.
Admin Approval Required for new accounts may slow creation of fake personas but does not prevent repurposing existing compromised ones.
evasion_considerations: Adopt tone, timing, and communication patterns that match real IT/security staff, referencing plausible internal projects or tickets to enhance credibility.
Use private DMs or small-group channels for the most sensitive misdirection to minimize the number of observers who might challenge the narrative.
Coordinate impersonation with technical evasion actions: for example, explain away missing audit data or retention changes as part of ‘compliance updates’.
Avoid overusing executive personas; instead, rely on mid-level IT or support roles that routinely make operational requests and are less likely to be double-checked.
vectors.comments: Here, impersonation is used specifically to weaken or delay defensive responses inside Slack—getting dangerous configurations approved and explaining away suspicious changes—rather than as a pure initial-access technique.
vectors.evasion_achieved: By appearing to be trusted internal staff or agents, the attacker can socially legitimize suspicious configuration and monitoring changes, reducing the likelihood that defenders treat those changes as signs of compromise.

preconditions_required: Attacker already controls a Slack admin or IdP/SSO admin account used to manage Slack authentication policies.
Slack is integrated with an IdP that allows granular MFA and conditional-access configuration.
Defenders rely heavily on MFA events and login anomalies as detection signals for Slack-related compromises.
constraints_encountered: MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication are initially strong barriers to compromise; this vector only becomes available after those barriers have been overcome.
IP Allowlisting and other network controls may still limit where logins can originate from; the attacker must operate from allowed locations or via compromised infrastructure.
Any changes to MFA or SSO policies may themselves be logged and monitored via Slack’s Audit Logs API or IdP logging; the attacker must keep such changes subtle and targeted.
evasion_considerations: Prefer adding attacker-controlled MFA devices rather than globally disabling MFA enforcement, to avoid conspicuous policy changes.
Apply MFA relaxations only to a narrow set of accounts that already behave like service or admin accounts, so that slight deviations in login patterns are less likely to stand out.
Time MFA-related changes during known maintenance windows or coincident with legitimate security projects so that they can be explained as part of those activities if questioned.
Use MFA-bypassed or attacker-registered accounts primarily for API and admin console access, keeping interactive UI use minimal and businesslike.
vectors.comments: Although MFA configuration is largely IdP-centric, Slack’s documented support for SSO and 2FA means that MFA weakening around Slack accounts can materially reduce detection and friction for attacker operations.
vectors.evasion_achieved: Slack admin and service accounts used by the attacker authenticate cleanly and repeatedly without suspicious MFA prompts or failures, reducing authentication-based alerts while preserving ongoing high-privilege access.

defense_evasion.summary: Within Slack, realistic defense evasion centers on abusing governance, identity, encryption, and app/automation features rather than tampering with underlying infrastructure. An attacker who has already obtained privileged identities or tokens can (1) degrade or subvert logging and monitoring by breaking or filtering Audit Logs API consumers and scheduled exports; (2) manipulate retention, legal holds, and EKM keys so that key periods of message/file history become unreadable or are rapidly purged; (3) operate primarily through OAuth-backed apps, AI agents, and background workflows using application access tokens that bypass MFA and blend into normal integration traffic; (4) rely on legitimate-looking cloud accounts and masqueraded names for users, bots, and agents to hide malicious actions behind trusted-seeming identities; (5) use impersonation via channels/DMs to socially legitimize suspicious changes and delay response; and (6) adjust MFA/SSO enforcement around Slack-related admin accounts to keep those footholds usable without drawing attention via repeated authentication challenges. Environment-wide constraints like MFA, SSO-only auth, IP allowlisting, and registration controls significantly raise the bar for initial compromise but, once bypassed, do not prevent these Slack-native defense evasion behaviors.

preconditions_required: Ability to register and host a Slack app under attacker control.
Ability to get at least one target workspace/org to install and authorize the app, typically by convincing an admin or owner to approve it due to the 'Admin Approval Required' environment constraint.
The app must be granted scopes that are actually valuable (for example, read access to messages/files or admin APIs); overly narrow scopes limit utility.
If IP Allowlisting is enforced for Slack access, the attacker’s app backend must be reachable and allowed by whatever outbound policies govern Slack’s callbacks and API calls.
constraints_encountered: MFA Required: Admins approving the app must complete MFA, but this protects their interactive login, not the OAuth tokens that the app ultimately receives.
SSO-Only Authentication: Human admins log into Slack via SSO; the OAuth flow rides on top of that session and is unaffected once the admin is logged in.
Admin Approval Required: Many orgs require explicit admin approval for new apps, forcing the attacker to target admins/owners specifically and craft a convincing pretext.
Rate Limiting: Use of stolen tokens for enumeration or data access is constrained by Slack’s API rate limits, requiring careful throttling.
IP Allowlisting: If the customer constrains Slack usage by source IP, the attacker may need to operate tokens from a compromised host or proxy within the allowlisted range.
evasion_considerations: Request scopes that appear plausible for the app’s purported function (for example, positioning as a project assistant or AI bot) to avoid admin scrutiny.
Distribute the app as an unlisted app with direct OAuth links rather than a public Marketplace listing if review friction is too high.
Throttle API usage from stolen tokens to stay below anomaly and rate-limiting thresholds and mimic normal app behavior patterns.
Implement token rotation and cleanup in attacker infrastructure to avoid leaving obvious artifacts of long-lived unused tokens.
vectors.comments: This is the most direct Slack-native implementation of MITRE T1528 (Steal Application Access Token): the stolen OAuth tokens are themselves the credentials. Real campaigns (e.g., APT28’s malicious OAuth apps) demonstrate the practicality of this pattern against cloud/SaaS platforms.
vectors.credentials_obtained: Slack OAuth access tokens (bot, user, and potentially high-privilege admin/app tokens) for one or more workspaces or an entire Enterprise org, functioning as reusable credentials that bypass the need for the human admin’s password or MFA.

preconditions_required: Prior compromise or insider access to environments where Slack-related secrets are stored (for example, CI/CD systems, admin laptops, or internal code repositories).
Developers or admins must be using Slack CLI, admin integrations, or custom apps that rely on long-lived tokens or service credentials.
Those tokens or secrets must be stored insecurely enough to be readable by the attacker (for example, checked into code, dumped to logs, or misconfigured in secret stores).
If the Slack org enforces IP Allowlisting, the attacker must be able to issue API calls from an allowed network using the stolen tokens.
constraints_encountered: MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication primarily protect interactive logins and do not prevent misuse of already-issued API tokens or CLI service tokens.
IP Allowlisting can limit where stolen tokens can be used, requiring the attacker to pivot through a host on an allowed network.
Rate Limiting on Slack APIs constrains mass enumeration with stolen tokens, but attackers can work around this with throttled or long-running collection.
evasion_considerations: Use stolen tokens sparingly and schedule operations to resemble normal automation or admin tooling behavior.
Favor existing high-privilege automation tokens (for example, those already calling admin or SCIM APIs) rather than creating obvious new admin-focused apps.
Avoid noisy APIs (such as mass deprovisioning) and focus on read-heavy, low-profile calls like listing users, channels, and reading messages/files via existing app scopes.
vectors.comments: This vector is a Slack-specific instance of MITRE T1552 (Unsecured Credentials): high-privilege Slack secrets (CLI service tokens, admin OAuth tokens, SCIM credentials) are stored outside Slack and become exposed through misconfiguration or poor operational practice, then reused to access Slack as highly privileged identities.
vectors.credentials_obtained: High-privilege Slack credentials including Slack CLI service tokens, admin/bot/user OAuth tokens, and SCIM/admin API bearer tokens extracted from insecure storage in CI/CD, admin tooling, or source repositories.

constraints_encountered: MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication make it harder to compromise initial user accounts, but once an account or app token is obtained, Slack does not re-prompt MFA for every API read.
Rate Limiting on Web and Events APIs constrains how fast the attacker can enumerate historical content, forcing slower or incremental scanning.

evasion_considerations: Prefer using a compromised legitimate app (for example, an existing integration with broad read scopes) rather than introducing a new, suspicious app.

Focus scanning on high-value teams and channels instead of performing exhaustive org-wide collection immediately.

Slack’s rich message, file, canvas, and list surfaces—and the ability to search or access them via APIs—make it particularly valuable as a credential repository for other systems.
vectors.credentials_obtained: Credentials and secrets for external systems (for example, cloud provider keys, database passwords, OAuth client secrets, SSH keys, access tokens, and shared passwords) that users have posted into Slack messages, files, canvases, lists, or Slack Connect channels.

credential_access.summary:
Slack presents multiple realistic credential access vectors grounded in its documented capabilities.

The highest-impact paths are:
- Stealing Slack OAuth access tokens (bot, user, and especially admin-scoped tokens) via malicious or compromised apps (T1528), either by tricking admins into installing attacker-controlled apps or by finding those tokens stored insecurely in developer/CI environments (T1552).
- Systematically mining Slack content for credentials to other systems (T9664) via compromised accounts or apps with read scopes, leveraging channels, DMs, files, canvases, lists, Slack Connect, and enterprise search to harvest API keys, passwords, and tokens shared in collaboration.
- Abusing enterprise export, Admin Oversight, and Legal Holds capabilities (also T9664) from a compromised Org/Workspace admin to export or query nearly all messages and files—including private channels and DMs—and then performing offline secret discovery across the resulting datasets.
- Repurposing AI agents and Agentforce-based apps (again T9664) as automated secret hunters: AI apps with assistant:write and broad read scopes can ingest large volumes of conversation context and, under attacker control, identify and exfiltrate embedded credentials.

Environmental constraints such as MFA, SSO-only authentication, CAPTCHA, and rate limiting significantly raise the bar for directly guessing or stuffing passwords against Slack logins, and those techniques (Password Guessing/Spraying, Credential Stuffing, MFA Request Generation, SAML/Web cookie forging, Hybrid Identity, Modify Authentication Process) are not realistically achievable using Slack’s exposed application features alone—they would require attacking the IdP, endpoints, or browsers, which is outside this app-focused analysis. However, once any Slack account or app token is compromised, those same constraints do little to prevent credential harvesting via the Slack capabilities described above.

Overall, the primary "crown jewels" from a credential-access perspective are (1) Slack OAuth/admin/SCIM/CLI tokens themselves, which grant powerful API-based access to Slack, and (2) the many non-Slack credentials users store in Slack content (cloud keys, database passwords, OAuth client secrets, SSH keys), which can be mined via APIs, exports, workflows, and AI agents to enable compromise of other critical systems.

preconditions_required: The attacker has compromised the backend or secrets store of at least one Slack app and can read its stored OAuth tokens.
The app is already installed (and where required, admin-approved) in one or more target Slack workspaces, ideally including Enterprise Grid organizations.

If IP Allowlisting is enabled, the attacker can originate API traffic from IP ranges that are allowlisted for the relevant workspaces (for example, by abusing the app’s existing infrastructure or corporate proxy ranges).
constraints_encountered: MFA Required – increases the difficulty of stealing the tokens initially, but once OAuth tokens are obtained they can be used against Slack APIs without MFA.
SSO-Only Authentication – similarly affects only how tokens were originally minted; token-based API access is independent of interactive SSO.
IP Allowlisting – Slack APIs will reject requests from non-allowlisted IP ranges, so the attacker must operate from infrastructure that matches the app’s expected egress IPs.
Rate Limiting – Web API and Admin API rate limits constrain large-scale enumeration and data access, forcing the attacker to throttle or distribute requests.
Admin Approval Required – limits the attacker’s ability to spread a malicious app into new workspaces; this vector primarily abuses already-installed integrations.
evasion_considerations: Route all malicious API calls through the app’s existing infrastructure and IP addresses so traffic patterns resemble legitimate integration usage.
Throttle enumeration and data access to remain well within documented rate limits and the app’s historical behavior profile.
Focus collection on a subset of high-value channels and workspaces instead of bulk-exporting all history at once, reducing anomalies in Audit Logs and SIEMs.
Avoid obvious administrative actions (for example, mass channel creation or permission changes) that would be visible to users and admins.
vectors.comments: This is one of the highest-impact Slack-specific lateral movement paths: a single compromised, widely installed app—particularly an admin-focused or eDiscovery-style app—can provide cross-workspace, cross-tenant visibility into messages, files, and Slack Connect channels and may also expose connected SaaS systems such as CRM or document platforms.
vectors.movement_achieved: Cross-workspace and cross-tenant access to Slack organizations (including Slack Connect channels) and pivot into connected SaaS systems by abusing compromised Slack app OAuth tokens.

The target Slack organization is configured to use SAML SSO with the compromised IdP (potentially in SSO-only mode).

constraints_encountered: MFA Required – protects direct password-based logins but is bypassed when the attacker uses forged SAML assertions or stolen Slack session cookies.
SSO-Only Authentication – concentrates all authentication risk in the IdP; the attacker must first succeed against SAML/IdP rather than Slack’s own login forms.

Rate Limiting – can restrict high-volume API-based enumeration once inside Slack, but moderate admin and user activity can blend into normal patterns.

The main crown jewels are high-sensitivity channels (executive, legal, incident response) and the ability to reconfigure memberships and app approvals from an impersonated admin account.
vectors.movement_achieved: Lateral movement from an IdP or endpoint compromise into one or more Slack workspaces, then expansion across workspaces and Slack Connect channels by impersonating high-privilege users using stolen or forged SAML assertions or session cookies.

preconditions_required: The attacker controls at least one Slack identity (user account or app) that can send messages within the target workspace or via Slack Connect to intended victims.
Target users are allowed to click external links and, where relevant, install or authorize Slack apps (subject to any admin-approval workflows).
Security awareness and technical controls for Slack-based phishing are imperfect, so some users may comply with malicious prompts.
constraints_encountered: MFA Required – reduces the value of simple password-harvesting phish, pushing attackers toward OAuth consent abuse or full session/token theft.
SSO-Only Authentication – concentrates account authentication in the IdP, so phishing campaigns must target SSO flows or OAuth consents that still produce usable tokens.
Admin Approval Required – can block immediate installation of malicious apps by end users; attackers may need to spearphish admins specifically or attempt to subvert the approval process.
Rate Limiting – very large-scale phishing via Slack messages may be anomalous or hit organizational controls; attackers will favor low-and-slow messages to a small number of high-value users.
evasion_considerations: Keep phishing volume low and highly targeted to resemble normal internal collaboration rather than bulk spam.
Use compromised, trusted accounts and existing ongoing threads to send lures, minimizing suspicion.
Mirror internal terminology, current projects, and formatting conventions (including Block Kit styling) to blend into legitimate communications.
vectors.comments: Internal spearphishing over Slack is a realistic and high-probability lateral movement method: a single compromised user can be used to compromise additional Slack and SSO identities, including admins, thereby expanding access to more workspaces, channels, and even connected SaaS systems.
vectors.movement_achieved: Expansion from an initial compromised Slack identity to additional Slack users—especially admins—and their associated workspaces, channels, and Slack Connect relationships by delivering targeted phishing content via trusted internal Slack communications.

vectors.comments: This technique relies on planting executable content in shared storage (for example network file shares or shared binaries) that is later executed on remote systems. Slack does support file sharing and integrations with document storage, but the documentation does not indicate that Slack itself behaves like an executable file share (e.g., auto-running code from shared files or modifying OS-level shortcuts). Any malware delivered via Slack files or links would execute in endpoint environments (Windows, macOS, etc.), not within Slack’s own SaaS environment. Because the ApplicationCapabilityAnalysis does not describe capabilities for modifying OS shortcuts, masquerading directories, or automatically executing shared binaries, this technique cannot be reliably modeled as a Slack-native lateral movement vector.
vectors.movement_achieved: Not achievable within Slack’s documented capabilities; file sharing in Slack does not provide the network-share execution semantics required for this technique.

vectors.comments: The Software Deployment Tools technique describes abusing centralized configuration-management and deployment platforms (such as SCCM, Intune, or cloud configuration managers) to execute code across many endpoints. Slack’s documented capabilities do not include a native endpoint-management or software-deployment service. While third-party deployment tools could expose Slack integrations (for example, posting job status into channels), the ApplicationCapabilityAnalysis does not document any specific connector that would allow an attacker, from inside Slack, to push arbitrary software or commands to endpoints. Without evidence of such a first-class or tightly coupled deployment capability, modeling this ATT&CK technique as a realistic Slack lateral movement vector would be speculative, so it is marked as not achievable.
vectors.movement_achieved: Not achievable using Slack’s own documented functionality; there is no native, central software-deployment mechanism to abuse for lateral movement.

lateral_movement.summary: Slack exposes several realistic lateral movement avenues grounded in its multi-workspace architecture, app platform, and identity model. The most significant are: (1) abuse of compromised Slack app OAuth tokens (Application Access Token) to pivot across many workspaces, Slack Connect channels, and even into connected SaaS systems; (2) use of alternate authentication material (forged SAML assertions or stolen Slack web sessions) to impersonate high-privilege users and expand access across Enterprise Grid workspaces and Slack Connect relationships; and (3) internal spearphishing via Slack messages, files, and interactive app surfaces to compromise additional Slack and SSO identities, especially admins, thereby widening access. Techniques like Taint Shared Content and Software Deployment Tools are not supported by Slack’s documented capabilities and do not constitute realistic Slack-native lateral movement vectors. Collectively, the achievable vectors primarily threaten crown jewels such as executive and incident channels, sensitive DMs, shared files, and data in integrated SaaS platforms (e.g., CRM, document stores) that are surfaced or orchestrated through Slack.

preconditions_required: Attacker controls a valid Slack user session (cookie, token, or device) for a target workspace, with MFA and SSO requirements already satisfied.

constraints_encountered: MFA Required – the attacker must already have a session or mechanism that bypasses or satisfies MFA; otherwise they cannot reach the Slack UI.
SSO-Only Authentication – if Slack is SSO-only, the attacker must compromise the identity provider or an active federated session rather than simple username/password.
IP Allowlisting – organizations may restrict Slack access to corporate IP ranges; collection must originate from an allowed IP (e.g., via a compromised VPN endpoint or workstation).
Rate Limiting – extremely heavy use of search and rapid file downloads may hit client-side or backend throttling and could appear anomalous in logs; attackers must operate low-and-slow.
evasion_considerations: Operate during local business hours and from typical client platforms (web/desktop) so access patterns resemble a normal user.
Favor targeted search queries and AI recaps over bulk scrolling of history to minimize volume and duration of visible activity.
Avoid joining new sensitive channels that might notify owners; focus collection on channels where the compromised user already has legitimate membership.
Limit the number and size of files downloaded in a short period to avoid sudden spikes in bandwidth or unusual file-access patterns.
If possible, rely on reading in-client rather than using programmatic exports, which are more likely to be monitored.

constraints_encountered: MFA Required – admin accounts are likely to be protected by MFA; compromises typically rely on stolen sessions, IdP compromise, or device takeover.
SSO-Only Authentication – if enabled, admin access depends on compromising the upstream identity provider or a device with an active SSO session.
IP Allowlisting – organizations may restrict admin console and API access to specific IP ranges; automated export and API access must originate from allowed addresses.
Rate Limiting – the Audit Logs and Oversight APIs, as well as underlying Web APIs, are subject to rate limiting, constraining how quickly bulk data can be pulled.

Use existing admin-focused integrations (e.g., SIEM connectors) and their tokens where possible instead of creating new high-privilege apps.
Throttle API calls and schedule them during typical maintenance or reporting windows to avoid anomalous traffic patterns.
Avoid making obviously suspicious retention changes (e.g., disabling retention globally); instead, rely more on legal holds to preserve data quietly.
vectors.comments: This vector treats Slack as a governed enterprise information repository. By abusing export, legal hold, and oversight tooling, an attacker can obtain full or near-full historical records of Slack communications and admin activity, often including DMs and private channels.
vectors.data_collected: Large-scale, structured archives of Slack content and governance data, including historical messages and files across channels, DMs, and Slack Connect, plus audit logs, legal hold scopes, and configuration metadata that together provide a comprehensive historical view of organizational communications.
