preconditions_required: A Slack app with sufficiently broad read scopes (e.g., message and file scopes, and optionally admin/scim scopes) is installed in the target workspace or Enterprise org, and the attacker controls its tokens or backend.
App governance allows either the installation of such an app or the continued operation of an already-installed integration.
If IP allowlisting is enforced, the app backend (or Socket Mode connection) must originate from allowlisted IP space (e.g., corporate network or an approved integration environment).
Relevant channels and DMs (including Slack Connect) permit the app to be present or have scopes that grant it visibility into their content.
constraints_encountered: IP Allowlisting – backend servers must send API and Events API traffic from IPs permitted by the organization’s Slack configuration.
Rate Limiting – Web API, Admin APIs, and Events API consumers are subject to rate limits; aggressive backfill or download operations must be throttled and retried carefully.

Admin Approval Required – in many enterprises, new apps or apps with sensitive scopes require explicit admin approval before they can be installed, limiting the ability to introduce a new malicious app.
MFA/SSO Constraints – while app-to-Slack communication uses tokens, obtaining or updating those tokens may require admin logins protected by SSO and MFA.
evasion_considerations: Request only the minimum Slack scopes necessary for the app to function, and describe them in a way that appears consistent with a benign business integration.
Operate the collector at a steady, low rate, respecting rate limits and avoiding sudden spikes in history backfills or file downloads.
Use unlisted distribution or internal-only apps rather than public Marketplace listings to avoid extra scrutiny.
Name and brand the app to resemble common integrations (e.g., analytics or reporting tools) to reduce the chance of removal during periodic app reviews.
If workflows are used, configure them under plausible business use cases (e.g., automated status reports) so that their behavior and channel presence do not appear suspicious.
vectors.comments: This vector automates what a human attacker could do via the UI, turning Slack into a continuous telemetry source. It closely mirrors real-world patterns where adversaries use cloud APIs and automation to harvest data from SaaS platforms over time.
vectors.data_collected: A continuously updated, machine-readable corpus of Slack data, including historical and real-time messages, DMs (where scopes allow), Slack Connect content, files, workflow payloads, and enriched identity and audit metadata, all staged in attacker-controlled storage for later analysis or exfiltration.

preconditions_required: Compromised user account or app token with visibility into channels/DMs where files of interest are shared (including Slack Connect shared spaces where relevant).
For Web API access, OAuth scopes that permit reading file metadata and content.
If using export-based bulk collection, admin privileges and plan level sufficient to enable exports that include file data.
constraints_encountered: Rate Limiting – bulk file downloads via Web API must respect rate limits; otherwise, API access could be throttled or temporarily blocked.
IP Allowlisting – if enforced, programmatic file downloads must originate from allowlisted IP ranges.
Data Retention – retention policies may delete older files, limiting the historical window available for collection.
Enterprise Key Management – if EKM keys have been revoked for specific workspaces/channels/time ranges, corresponding files may be inaccessible even to otherwise-privileged accounts.
evasion_considerations: Prioritize a smaller set of high-value files rather than mass-downloading all available documents to avoid bandwidth anomalies and suspicious activity patterns.
Distribute downloads over time and across different channels/DMs to reduce the chance of triggering alerts tied to specific workspaces or users.
Use standard client downloads where feasible, as they are common user actions, and rely on Web API only when automation is needed.
Avoid altering file permissions or sharing settings, which could alert data owners; instead, rely on existing access that the compromised identity already has.
vectors.comments: Slack functions as a cloud storage layer for many sensitive documents, from incident reports to exported customer datasets. Treating Slack as a storage service and systematically harvesting its files is directly analogous to adversaries dumping data from S3, OneDrive, or other cloud object stores.
vectors.data_collected: Collections of documents and binary artifacts stored in Slack’s cloud-backed file system, including internal reports, exports from other SaaS systems, design documents, financial spreadsheets, and attachments shared in channels, DMs, and Slack Connect conversations.

collection.summary: From a collection perspective, Slack exposes multiple rich avenues for gathering sensitive data once an attacker controls a user, admin, or app identity. At the low end, a compromised user can mine channels, DMs, and Slack Connect spaces via the normal UI and search/Slack AI features, harvesting chat logs, incident-response chatter, and attachments—precisely the behavior documented in the Messaging Applications technique. At the governance layer, compromised admins can abuse data exports, legal holds, and oversight/Audit Logs APIs to pull large, structured archives of Slack communications and metadata from the platform as an information repository. Platform-level integrations, particularly OAuth apps and Workflow Builder automations, enable fully automated, continuous collection of messages, files, and identity data via Web, Events, Admin, and SCIM APIs. Finally, Slack’s role as cloud file storage allows targeted harvesting of uploaded documents and exports, treating Slack much like an object store. Environmental controls such as MFA, SSO-only authentication, IP allowlisting, and API rate limiting constrain how these vectors can be used but do not fundamentally prevent them once a valid identity or app token has been compromised or misused.

preconditions_required: Attacker controls at least one valid Slack account (user or bot) in the target workspace that has passed SSO-only authentication and MFA, and can send/receive messages.
An OAuth token or other reusable authentication material for Web API access is available to the attacker and can read/write in the chosen C2 conversation.
Compromised endpoints are able to reach Slack’s public HTTPS endpoints; if IP allowlisting is enforced, they must sit within allowed ranges or proxy through allowed infrastructure.
Organization app and security policies do not block the use of this account or token for API access to channels/DMs.
constraints_encountered: MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication make it harder to newly compromise accounts, but once an OAuth token or session is obtained, subsequent Web API use for C2 does not require re-performing MFA for each request.

IP Allowlisting may prevent external infrastructure from directly talking to Slack APIs; the malware must run from allowlisted networks (e.g., inside the corporate environment) or tunnel traffic through an allowed proxy.
Rate Limiting on Web API endpoints will constrain very high-frequency polling; C2 agents must use low-and-slow polling intervals and caching to stay under limits.
Admin Approval Required and Domain-Based Registration restrict creation of new accounts; attackers are pushed toward reusing existing compromised identities for this vector.
evasion_considerations: Use low-frequency polling and jitter to avoid triggering rate limits or anomalous traffic patterns in SIEMs consuming Audit Logs API data.
Give the C2 channel or DM an innocuous name and occasional legitimate-looking chatter to blend with normal collaboration.
Encrypt or encode command and result payloads within messages or files so defenders cannot easily interpret them from message audits.
Prefer private channels or small DMs with low membership to reduce the chance of accidental discovery by other users.
vectors.comments: This vector treats Slack itself as the external web service for malware C2: compromised endpoints talk to Slack over HTTPS using valid tokens, and operators issue instructions via Slack messages. It requires only standard messaging and Web API capabilities, so it works even in environments with strict app-approval policies, as long as the attacker can obtain a token.
vectors.communication_established: Bidirectional HTTPS-based command channel between compromised endpoints and the attacker is implemented using Slack messages in a private channel or DM accessed via the Web API.

constraints_encountered: App governance and admin approval workflows can block or delay installation of untrusted apps; the attacker must either compromise an admin, abuse a trusted vendor app, or blend into legitimate workflows.
MFA Required, SSO-Only Authentication, and Domain-Based Registration make it harder to create new admin accounts, pushing attackers toward compromising existing admins to approve the app.
Rate Limiting on Web API and Events API can expose very noisy or abusive apps; the attacker must keep C2 traffic within normal behavioral bounds.

evasion_considerations: Request only the minimum OAuth scopes necessary for C2 to avoid security-team scrutiny and to look like a normal productivity integration.
Use benign branding and descriptions in the app and Marketplace listing so it appears consistent with business workflows.
Throttle events and API calls, and avoid bulk operations that might create obvious spikes in Audit Logs or SIEM alerts.
Route sensitive exfiltration and operator communications over a separate attacker-controlled channel so that the Slack app’s visible behavior remains low risk.
vectors.comments: This vector uses Slack’s app platform as the primary C2 mechanism: Slack pushes events and interactions to the attacker-controlled backend over HTTPS/WebSockets, and the backend issues Web API calls back into Slack. To defenders, this appears as a standard app integration using web protocols.
vectors.communication_established: Persistent HTTPS/WebSocket-based command channel between Slack and an attacker-controlled app backend using Events API callbacks/Socket Mode plus Web API requests.

preconditions_required: A compromised user account with permissions to create and edit workflows in at least one workspace.
Workflow governance settings that allow user-authored workflows to run with sufficient access to targeted channels/surfaces.
Knowledge of, and continued access to, the secret webhook URL associated with the workflow trigger.

constraints_encountered: MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication make it harder to compromise the workflow author account, but once compromised they do not limit webhook-triggered executions.
Rate Limiting and potential throttling on webhook-triggered workflows mean the attacker must avoid sending bursts of triggers that could stand out operationally.
Admin-driven workflow governance may restrict who can create workflows or require review of workflows that post to sensitive channels, which could expose the malicious automation.
IP Allowlisting does not typically affect Slack’s hosted webhook endpoints, but may restrict where the attacker can log into Slack to monitor workflow outputs.
evasion_considerations: Name the workflow and its target channels to match legitimate business processes (e.g., “Ops metrics updater”) so occasional automated posts look normal.
Limit how frequently the webhook is triggered and keep payload sizes modest to blend in with typical automation patterns.
Use existing connectors to popular SaaS tools rather than obvious custom endpoints when exfiltrating or returning data externally.
Design the workflow’s actions so they appear as benign operational updates rather than obviously suspicious changes or mass notifications.
vectors.comments: This vector uses Slack’s webhook-triggered workflows as a programmable agent inside the workspace. An attacker who knows the webhook URL can drive actions and indirect data flows purely via HTTPS requests, even if no custom app has been installed.
vectors.communication_established: Inbound HTTPS-based command channel from attacker infrastructure into Slack via workflow webhook triggers, with responses encoded in workflow outputs (messages, list/canvas updates, or connector calls).

command_and_control.summary: Slack exposes multiple realistic command-and-control avenues grounded in its messaging, app, workflow, Slack Connect, and AI agent capabilities. An attacker with a compromised account or app token can use standard channels and DMs plus the Web API to run HTTPS-based C2 between malware and Slack. Malicious or compromised apps can receive Events API and interactivity callbacks and respond via Web API calls, forming a full duplex web-protocol C2 channel between Slack and attacker infrastructure. Workflow Builder with webhook triggers allows external HTTPS requests to drive in-Slack automations, providing another C2 entry point even without custom code. Slack Connect shared channels and DMs create persistent cross-organization paths that attackers can use to coordinate with compromised insiders or bots from an external workspace. Finally, AI-enabled agents and LLM-backed apps can act as autonomous operators that shuttle Slack conversation data to attacker-controlled AI backends and execute actions based on remote instructions. Environmental constraints like MFA, SSO-only auth, IP allowlisting, and admin app-approval workflows increase the difficulty of initial compromise and app installation but do not eliminate these vectors once valid accounts or tokens are under attacker control.

preconditions_required: Victim organization must be on a plan that supports the desired export scope (e.g., Business+ or Enterprise for self-serve export of all channels and conversations; Discovery APIs for full eDiscovery/DLP integrations).
Attacker must control or impersonate an Org Owner / Workspace Owner / Admin with rights to configure and run exports and, where relevant, to authorize Discovery API apps.

constraints_encountered: MFA Required – makes compromising admin sessions and tokens harder but does not impede exports once the attacker has valid admin access.
SSO-Only Authentication – requires the attacker to compromise the organization’s IdP account or SSO session rather than a standalone Slack password.
IP Allowlisting – requires the attacker to operate from, or proxy through, allowlisted IP ranges to reach the admin console and download exports.
Admin Approval Required – in some organizations, enabling Discovery APIs or specific eDiscovery apps may require extra approvals, slowing or surfacing malicious configuration changes.
Rate Limiting – Discovery API and related endpoints are likely rate-limited, but exports are batch-oriented and can be scheduled, so limits primarily influence speed rather than feasibility.
evasion_considerations: Run exports during maintenance windows or at times when legitimate discovery activity is expected to reduce suspicion.
Scope initial exports to specific users or date ranges to appear aligned with plausible investigations, then slowly expand scope.
Leverage existing, approved eDiscovery/DLP integrations instead of registering a new app, altering only backend destinations where possible.
Avoid frequent changes to export settings or legal holds that would stand out in audit logs or change management reviews.

interfaces_used: Events API event subscriptions and delivery to app endpoints (https://docs.slack.dev/apis/events-api/)
Interactivity request URL configuration for shortcuts, slash commands, and interactive components (https://docs.slack.dev/interactivity/)
Web API HTTP methods for reading channels, messages, and files (https://docs.slack.dev/apis/web-api/)
data_accessed: All messages and files in channels/DMs where the app has membership and read scopes
User-entered data via slash commands, shortcuts, and interactive modals
Message and file metadata (timestamps, user_ids, channel_ids, file_ids, titles, sizes)
Potentially additional history retrieved via conversations and file-related Web API methods
preconditions_required: The target workspace/org must allow installation of custom or Marketplace apps; completely app‑blocked tenants substantially reduce feasibility.
Attacker must get an app installed with sufficiently broad read scopes, either by social-engineering users/admins, compromising an existing app, or abusing existing admin privileges.
Events API and/or interactivity must be enabled for the app so Slack will push webhook-style payloads to the attacker-controlled endpoint.
Environmental controls (MFA, SSO-only auth, IP allowlisting, Admin Approval Required) must have been bypassed or satisfied to install and configure the app.
constraints_encountered: Admin Approval Required – many orgs require explicit admin approval for any app with read scopes over messages/files, which can block or delay malicious app installation.
App governance allowlists/denylists – some orgs only permit pre-approved Marketplace apps, forcing attackers to compromise an existing app rather than introduce a new one.
MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication – increase the difficulty of abusing privileged accounts for app approval or configuration changes.
Rate Limiting – Web API and Events API throttling constrain how fast bulk history can be pulled; attackers may need to pace API calls to avoid errors or obvious spikes.
evasion_considerations: Disguise the app as a common productivity or AI assistant with a plausible business purpose to reduce scrutiny during approval.
Request only the minimum set of scopes initially, then escalate over time via updates once trust has been established.
Throttle exfiltration and batch uploads to external services to blend in with normal app traffic and avoid rate limiting spikes.
Limit subscriptions initially to a subset of channels or users to avoid raising suspicion, expanding scope gradually.
vectors.comments: This vector mirrors many documented real-world SaaS abuses where legitimate app platforms are used as high-bandwidth exfil channels via event webhooks and APIs.
vectors.data_exfiltrated: Continuous or batched streams of channel and DM messages, file content and metadata, and user-input from interactive workflows, all pushed via webhook-style payloads and subsequent HTTPS API calls from Slack to attacker-controlled web services.

method_steps.description: Using a compromised regular or power user account with Workflow Builder permissions, open the Workflow Builder UI in Slack to create or edit a workflow.
related_interfaces: Workflow Builder UI (https://slack.com/help/articles/360035692513-Guide-to-Slack-Workflow-Builder)
Help Center – Connect tools & automate tasks (https://slack.com/help/categories/360000047926)
related_data: Workflow definitions (triggers, steps, parameters)
User and channel references used by the workflow
method_steps.notes: Workflow creation may itself be governed by admin policies, but many organizations allow team-level automation.

method_steps.description: Define a trigger that captures the desired Slack data, such as “when a message is posted in selected channels,” “on a schedule,” or a form-based trigger that users invoke manually.
related_interfaces: Trigger configuration in Workflow Builder (event and schedule triggers)
Interactivity and automatic invocation docs (https://docs.slack.dev/interactivity/)
related_data: Message text, user_ids, channel_ids, timestamps from triggering events
Form input values if using form-based triggers
method_steps.notes: Scheduled triggers support periodic bulk export; message-based triggers support near-real-time streaming of channel activity.

method_steps.description: Add workflow steps that call out to third-party connectors or HTTP-like actions so that Slack sends the captured fields (message text, user names, file URLs, etc.) to external SaaS tools or custom endpoints controlled by the attacker.
related_capabilities: Slack-to-third-party app and AI provider flow
related_interfaces: Connector configuration surfaces inside Workflow Builder (Connect tools & automate tasks category)
Deno Slack SDK webhook triggers and related docs (https://docs.slack.dev/tools/deno-slack-sdk/guides/creating-webhook-triggers)
related_data: Structured payloads containing Slack message content, file links, user identifiers, and form data
Any additional context fields the workflow maps into connector requests
method_steps.notes: Connectors may effectively act as managed webhooks, posting JSON to external services over HTTPS.

method_steps.description: Configure third-party connectors (e.g., CRM, ticketing, spreadsheet, or generic webhook endpoints) with credentials and destination accounts that the attacker controls or can later access.
related_interfaces: Connector authentication and configuration dialogs within Workflow Builder
External SaaS configuration pages for connected accounts (outside Slack)
related_data: OAuth tokens or API keys for third-party connectors (stored by the connector app)
Identifiers for destination objects (e.g., spreadsheets, tickets, records) in the external system
method_steps.notes: In many organizations, connectors to popular SaaS tools are pre-approved, making it easier to hide exfiltration in legitimate-looking destinations.

method_steps.description: Publish the workflow so that it runs automatically. Each time the trigger condition is met, Slack sends a webhook-style request—via the connector or trigger—to the external service, carrying the selected Slack data.
related_interfaces: Workflow execution engine invoked by triggers (https://docs.slack.dev/workflows/comparing-workflows-apps/)
Connect tools & automate tasks workflows (https://slack.com/help/categories/360000047926)
related_data: Ongoing stream of trigger data (messages, user details, file URLs) sent to external services
Workflow execution logs describing each run
method_steps.notes: This yields automated exfiltration: Slack is continuously posting data to external web services without further user interaction.

method_steps.description: Optionally expand the workflow to cover additional channels or run on a schedule across multiple workspaces in an Enterprise org, increasing the volume and variety of data sent out.
related_interfaces: Admin controls for workflow permissions (https://docs.slack.dev/admins/)
Workflow Builder multi-channel / multi-workspace configuration (implicit from comparison docs)
related_data: Messages and metadata from more channels and workspaces
Additional user and channel identifiers
method_steps.notes: Careful scoping helps avoid immediate detection; exfil can be grown gradually.

capabilities_used: File sharing and contextual document collaboration
Slack-to-third-party app and AI provider flow
interfaces_used: Connect tools & automate tasks help and connectors (https://slack.com/help/categories/360000047926)
Deno Slack SDK webhook trigger docs (https://docs.slack.dev/tools/deno-slack-sdk/guides/creating-webhook-triggers)
Admin docs for workflow permissions and governance (https://docs.slack.dev/admins/)
data_accessed: Messages and metadata from channels tied to workflow triggers
File URLs or references included in messages or collected via workflow inputs
Free-form text and structured form inputs submitted through workflow steps
User identifiers and channel identifiers associated with each trigger event
preconditions_required: User accounts controlled by the attacker must have permission to create and publish workflows, including access to the relevant channels.
Third-party connectors or webhook-style actions used by the workflow must be installed and approved in the workspace.
External SaaS accounts or endpoints used as destinations must be under attacker control or accessible to them.
Workflow governance must not restrict high‑risk connectors or require separate admin approval for publishing the workflow.
constraints_encountered: Admin Approval Required – some organizations require admin review for workflows that use certain connectors or touch sensitive data.
App governance policies may restrict which third-party connectors can be used, forcing attackers to work with already-approved destinations.
Rate Limiting on connectors or workflows can slow high-volume exfiltration, encouraging more incremental leaks.
MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication complicate compromise of users with workflow permissions but do not constrain workflow execution once created.
evasion_considerations: Disguise workflows as legitimate automations (e.g., “Customer Sync” or “Channel Archive Helper”) that plausibly move data to external CRMs or documentation systems.
Scope initial workflows narrowly (few channels, limited fields) and ramp up gradually to avoid sudden spikes in connector usage.
Leverage existing, trusted connectors and destinations rather than creating obviously suspicious new endpoints.
Use scheduled triggers with modest cadence (e.g., nightly) instead of near-real-time streaming to blend into typical batch-job patterns.
vectors.comments: Workflow Builder effectively gives non-developers the power to configure webhook-like data flows out of Slack; a compromised power user can turn this into a persistent, low-code exfiltration pipeline.
vectors.data_exfiltrated: Streams or batches of messages, file links, and structured form data from targeted channels and workflows, automatically posted over HTTPS via connectors or webhook-style steps to external SaaS accounts or custom endpoints controlled by the attacker.

method_steps.description: Set up or control a separate Slack workspace or Enterprise org that the attacker owns, representing the attacker-controlled cloud account on the same SaaS platform.
related_interfaces: Slack signup and workspace management flows (https://slack.com/get-started, https://slack.com/help/categories/200122103)
related_data: New workspace_id or enterprise_id under attacker control
Attacker-owned user accounts and domains
method_steps.notes: Domain-Based Registration can limit which domains can sign up to a given corporate Slack, but the attacker can independently create or purchase a separate Slack tenant they control.

method_steps.description: Using a compromised user or admin account in the victim organization, initiate Slack Connect to share a sensitive existing channel or to create a new shared channel/DM with the attacker’s workspace.
related_interfaces: Slack Connect channel/DM creation and invite flows (https://slack.com/connect/)
Slack Connect admin security configuration (https://slack.com/resources/slack-for-admins/slack-connect-security)
related_data: Channel identifiers and metadata for channels being shared
Connection and invitation metadata linking the two organizations
method_steps.notes: Slack Connect policies determine which internal users can create connections and which external domains are allowed, so the attacker’s workspace/domain must be permitted or approved.

method_steps.description: From the attacker-controlled workspace, accept the Slack Connect invitation so that the chosen channel or DM becomes a shared channel between the victim org and the attacker’s org.
related_interfaces: Slack Connect invite acceptance flow in the attacker’s workspace (https://slack.com/connect/)
related_data: Shared channel_id used across both organizations
Membership lists spanning users from both tenants
method_steps.notes: Once accepted, messages and files in the shared channel are available in both orgs, subject to each org’s retention policies.

method_steps.description: Populate the shared channel/DM with sensitive content by sharing or copying information from internal-only channels and DMs into the Slack Connect channel, or by configuring teams to use the shared channel for ongoing project work that naturally carries the crown jewels.
related_capabilities: File sharing and contextual document collaboration
Workspaces with canvases and lists (Work Operating System)
related_interfaces: Channel/DM messaging UIs (https://slack.com/team-chat/)
Canvases and lists surfaces that can be attached to channels (https://docs.slack.dev/surfaces/)
related_data: Messages and files reposted or newly posted into the shared Slack Connect channel
Embedded canvases/lists and their content, where used
method_steps.notes: Some organizations also support sharing existing channels via Slack Connect, in which case historic content becomes visible to the attacker’s tenant once sharing is established.

method_steps.description: From the attacker-controlled Slack workspace, access the shared channel and use standard Slack clients or apps in that workspace to further export the replicated content (e.g., via data exports, apps, or manual downloads).
related_capabilities: Data export, discovery, and legal holds
related_interfaces: Shared channel view in the attacker’s workspace (https://slack.com/connect/)
Data export and Discovery API mechanisms in the attacker’s own org (https://slack.com/help/articles/204897248-Guide-to-Slack-import-and-export-tools)
related_data: Copy of victim messages and file links as stored in the attacker’s workspace
Any subsequent exports or app-collected datasets from the shared channels
method_steps.notes: From the victim’s perspective, data has been transferred to another cloud account (the attacker’s Slack org); subsequent exfil from that org is outside the victim’s control.

capabilities_used: File sharing and contextual document collaboration
Workspaces with canvases and lists (Work Operating System)
Data export, discovery, and legal holds
interfaces_used: Slack Connect security and governance settings (https://slack.com/resources/slack-for-admins/slack-connect-security)
Standard channel and DM message/file UIs (https://slack.com/team-chat/)
Canvases and lists surfaces attached to channels (https://docs.slack.dev/surfaces/)
data_accessed: All messages and files posted in the shared Slack Connect channels/DMs between victim and attacker’s organizations
Any canvases and lists attached to those shared channels
Slack Connect channel metadata indicating participants, history access, and retention behavior
preconditions_required: Slack Connect must be enabled in the victim organization, and policies must allow creating shared channels/DMs with external workspaces.
The attacker must control a separate Slack workspace/org and a domain or accounts that the victim’s Slack Connect governance will accept or can be tricked into approving.
A compromised internal account must have permission to initiate Slack Connect invites or share existing channels.
Org admins must approve the specific Slack Connect relationship if approvals are required by policy.
constraints_encountered: Slack Connect governance – domain allowlists, approval workflows, and restrictions on who can create connections may block arbitrary external domains, forcing attackers to mimic trusted partners.
MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication make compromising the internal account used to initiate sharing more difficult.
IP Allowlisting can constrain where the compromised internal user can operate from when configuring Slack Connect.
Retention policies in each org can limit how long replicated data persists in each tenant, potentially reducing historical leakage.
evasion_considerations: Use a seemingly legitimate external domain and workspace name that aligns with expected partners (e.g., a lookalike vendor) to gain approval for Slack Connect.
Share channels that already have some external collaboration justification, so the presence of an external org appears normal.
Encourage teams to conduct high-value discussions in the shared channel under the guise of streamlining partner communication.
Rely on differential retention: even if the victim later deletes or revokes access, the attacker’s workspace may retain the previously synced content according to its own policies.
vectors.comments: Slack Connect effectively extends the trust boundary to another Slack tenant; if that tenant is attacker-controlled, it becomes a sanctioned cross-cloud replication path for sensitive conversations and files.
vectors.data_exfiltrated: Messages, files, and associated artifacts from shared Slack Connect channels and DMs are replicated into an attacker-controlled Slack workspace/org, where they can be further exported or analyzed outside the victim’s administrative control.

method_steps.description: Develop or compromise an AI-enabled Slack app or agent (including Agentforce-style agents) that integrates with an external LLM or AI service and can operate on Slack conversation context.
related_capabilities: Agentforce and AI agents in Slack
Developer tools: Slack CLI, Bolt frameworks, SDKs, and sandboxes
related_interfaces: AI and agents overview (https://docs.slack.dev/ai/)
Developing AI apps – assistant threads and streaming (https://docs.slack.dev/ai/developing-ai-apps)
Agentforce configuration in Salesforce / Slack (https://slack.com/ai-agents/)
related_data: Agent configuration (skills, prompts, allowed actions)
Assistant thread identifiers and context settings
method_steps.notes: Docs explicitly note AI apps must mitigate data exfiltration risks when sending Slack data to LLMs, implying this is a known vector.

method_steps.description: Obtain installation of the AI app/agent in the target workspace with assistant:write and any necessary read scopes so it can receive conversation history and user prompts.
related_capabilities: OAuth-based authentication and tokens for apps
related_interfaces: OAuth 2.0 installation flows with AI-related scopes (https://docs.slack.dev/authentication/installing-with-oauth)
Agents & AI Apps enablement and scope configuration (https://docs.slack.dev/ai/)
Admin app approval UI/APIs (https://docs.slack.dev/admins/managing-app-approvals)
related_data: OAuth tokens with assistant:write and read scopes
Workspace/org configuration enabling Agents & AI Apps
method_steps.notes: Guests are documented as unable to access apps with Agents & AI Apps enabled, but regular members and admins can; app approval may be required.

method_steps.description: When users invoke the agent (via mentions, slash commands, or other entry points), allow Slack to send assistant-thread context including recent channel or DM history, referenced files, and user prompts to the AI app backend.
related_capabilities: File sharing and contextual document collaboration
related_interfaces: Assistant thread events and methods (assistant_thread_started, assistant_thread_context_changed, assistant.threads.*) (https://docs.slack.dev/ai/developing-ai-apps)
Chat streaming APIs (chat.startStream, chat.appendStream, chat.stopStream) (https://docs.slack.dev/ai/developing-ai-apps#streaming)
related_data: Channel and thread histories used as AI context
User prompts and any quoted messages
File references and possibly file content if fetched by the app
method_steps.notes: The richer the context windows configured for the agent, the more historic and sensitive data each invocation may expose.

method_steps.description: In the AI app backend, forward the received context and prompts to an external LLM or AI service over HTTPS, while logging or storing the full request payloads (including Slack-derived data) in attacker-controlled storage.
related_capabilities: Slack-to-third-party app and AI provider flow
related_interfaces: External AI provider HTTP APIs (outside Slack)
App backend logic that mediates assistant thread requests
related_data: Serialized conversation snippets, user prompts, and file content or summaries
Model inputs and outputs stored for later analysis by the attacker
method_steps.notes: Unlike Slack’s own AI (which is documented as zero-retention within Slack/AWS), third-party or custom AI apps may retain this data indefinitely.

method_steps.description: Use streaming APIs to progressively send larger document segments or entire long-running conversations to the external AI service, capturing the streamed content in logs or external databases.
related_interfaces: chat.startStream/chat.appendStream/chat.stopStream Web API methods (https://docs.slack.dev/ai/developing-ai-apps#streaming)
related_data: Chunks of conversation- or document-derived text streamed as LLM input/output
Metadata about which channels/threads and users each stream relates to
method_steps.notes: This can resemble legitimate AI usage, but the backend’s retention and export behaviors turn it into an exfiltration pipeline.

capabilities_used: Agentforce and AI agents in Slack
OAuth-based authentication and tokens for apps
File sharing and contextual document collaboration
Slack-to-third-party app and AI provider flow
interfaces_used: AI and agents overview and configuration docs (https://docs.slack.dev/ai/)
Developing AI apps docs covering assistant threads and streaming (https://docs.slack.dev/ai/developing-ai-apps)
Agentforce / AI agents in Slack marketing and configuration (https://slack.com/ai-agents/)
OAuth installation and scopes reference for AI apps (https://docs.slack.dev/authentication/installing-with-oauth, https://docs.slack.dev/reference/scopes)
data_accessed: High-value channel and DM histories chosen for AI summarization or Q&A
File content or extracts when agents are allowed to open referenced documents
User prompts that may contain sensitive questions or copied content
Derived summaries and AI-generated text, which may be stored alongside inputs
preconditions_required: Agents & AI Apps must be enabled in the workspace, and admins must allow the specific AI app/agent to be installed.
The AI app must be granted assistant:write and whatever message/file read scopes are needed to assemble context.
Users must actually use the agent on channels/DMs containing crown-jewel data (e.g., executive channels, incident rooms).
External AI provider integrations used by the app must be reachable and permitted by the organization’s outbound policies.
constraints_encountered: App governance and Admin Approval Required for AI apps can significantly limit which agents and AI assistants can be installed.
MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication can make it harder to compromise admins and approve rogue AI apps.
Rate Limiting on assistant and streaming APIs constrains how quickly very large volumes can be summarized or exported via AI calls.
Some organizations may have explicit policies against sending certain regulated data (e.g., PHI, PCI) to external AI providers, increasing detection risk.
evasion_considerations: Present the agent as an internal productivity assistant (e.g., “Project Recap Bot”) to encourage users to run it on sensitive channels.
Align AI prompts and outputs with normal business workflows (status reports, meeting summaries) to make traffic and usage patterns appear legitimate.
Store exfiltrated context and summaries in an external AI or analytics environment that already receives other organizational data, blending into normal integration flows.
Throttle usage and avoid obviously excessive context windows that might draw attention from admins reviewing AI app access.
vectors.comments: AI agents concentrate and repackage high-value Slack content into single requests to external LLMs, making each interaction disproportionately rich from an exfiltration standpoint.
vectors.data_exfiltrated: Rich conversational context (messages, threads, document excerpts, and user prompts) from targeted channels and DMs, transmitted as inputs and streamed tokens to external AI/LLM services and retained in attacker-controlled AI backends.

method_steps.description: Obtain or hijack an admin-focused integration (or create a new one) with access to Admin APIs such as the Audit Logs API, Admin Oversight API, SCIM API, and Legal Holds API.
related_capabilities: Audit Logs API and Admin Oversight API
related_interfaces: Admin developer docs (https://docs.slack.dev/admins/)
Audit Logs API reference (https://docs.slack.dev/admins/audit-logs-api/)
Admin Oversight API reference (https://docs.slack.dev/admins/admin-oversight-api)
Legal Holds API reference (https://docs.slack.dev/admins/legal-holds-api/)
SCIM API docs (https://docs.slack.dev/admins/scim-api/)
related_data: Admin-scoped OAuth tokens with admin.* and audit/oversight scopes
Integration configuration (target SIEM URLs, polling intervals)
method_steps.notes: These integrations are typically used to send Slack data to customer SIEMs and compliance tools; a compromise lets an attacker piggyback on that flow.

method_steps.description: Configure the integration so that it retrieves high-value governance data (audit logs, oversight-selected messages/channels, legal hold scopes, and full user/group directories) at a frequent cadence.
related_capabilities: Audit Logs API and Admin Oversight API
related_interfaces: Audit Logs API endpoints for event retrieval (https://docs.slack.dev/admins/audit-logs-api/)
Admin Oversight API endpoints for governed message/channel access
Legal Holds API endpoints for listing and scoping holds
SCIM endpoints for listing users and groups (https://docs.slack.dev/admins/scim-api/)

Selected message and channel content accessible under oversight policy
Legal hold definitions and lists of preserved custodians/channels
Complete user and group directories, including emails and roles
method_steps.notes: Even where message content via Oversight is constrained, the combination of logs and directory data is highly sensitive for further targeting.

related_capabilities: Security monitoring, logging, and incident management
related_interfaces: Customer SIEM/monitoring ingestion endpoints (outside Slack)
Integration configuration for Audit Logs/oversight exports
related_data: Continuous stream of audit and oversight data delivered over HTTPS
Bulk SCIM exports of user and group records
method_steps.notes: This often looks exactly like normal security monitoring behavior; the risk arises when the attacker controls or abuses the destination.

method_steps.description: Optionally, broaden legal holds or oversight scopes (via Legal Holds API or admin UIs) to preserve and expose more message content and channels to these admin APIs for later export.
related_capabilities: Data export, discovery, and legal holds
related_interfaces: Legal Holds API for defining and updating holds (https://docs.slack.dev/admins/legal-holds-api/)
Admin UIs for legal holds and oversight configuration
related_data: Expanded lists of preserved users/channels/timeframes
Additional message and file content held beyond normal retention
method_steps.notes: Misuse of holds can silently increase the volume and time range of data available to oversight and export mechanisms.

Security monitoring, logging, and incident management
Data export, discovery, and legal holds
interfaces_used: Admin developer documentation and API references (https://docs.slack.dev/admins/)
data_accessed: Detailed audit logs of logins, configuration changes, app installations, and other admin-relevant events
Selected channel and message content exposed via Admin Oversight for compliance or supervision
Legal hold definitions and information on which content is preserved beyond normal retention
Organization-wide user and group listings, including emails, roles, and group memberships
preconditions_required: The victim must be an Enterprise-tier customer with access to the Audit Logs, Admin Oversight, Legal Holds, and SCIM APIs.
An integration or app with the required high-privilege scopes must either exist and be compromised or be created and approved by admins.
The external SIEM/monitoring or compliance platform receiving the data must be reachable and under attacker control or influence.
constraints_encountered: MFA Required and SSO-Only Authentication significantly increase the difficulty of compromising the admin accounts needed to configure these APIs.
Admin Approval Required and strict app governance may limit the creation of new admin-scoped apps, forcing attackers to target existing integrations.
Rate Limiting applies to admin and audit APIs, potentially slowing bulk pulls but not blocking them over time.
IP Allowlisting may require the integration to connect from specific IPs, which the attacker must operate from or proxy through.
evasion_considerations: Piggyback on an existing, approved SIEM or compliance integration and modify its configuration, instead of registering a new integration.
Align polling frequencies and data volumes with prior baselines so that new exfiltration does not cause obvious spikes.
Focus on exporting metadata (logs, directories) first, which is expected for monitoring, then add more content via oversight mechanisms gradually.
Use legitimate justifications (e.g., expanded compliance requirements) if configuration changes are likely to be reviewed by humans.
vectors.comments: While these APIs are designed for security and compliance visibility, they also aggregate some of the most sensitive operational and identity data in the tenant; compromise of these paths provides a high-fidelity view of the environment in addition to limited content access.
vectors.data_exfiltrated: Comprehensive audit event streams, selected message and channel content under oversight, legal hold scopes, and full user/group directories exported via HTTPS to external monitoring, SIEM, or compliance platforms controlled or accessed by the attacker.

exfiltration.summary:
Given Slack’s capabilities and documented APIs, exfiltration is realistically achievable through multiple channels.

The most powerful vectors are admin-level exports and governance APIs, which can bulk-export organization-wide message history and files via self-serve export tools and Discovery APIs to external eDiscovery/DLP platforms (Exfiltration Over Web Service). Admin-focused integrations using the Audit Logs, Admin Oversight, Legal Holds, and SCIM APIs can continuously stream audit data, limited content, and full user/group directories over HTTPS to external SIEMs—providing a rich operational and identity dataset outside Slack’s control.

Slack’s extensible app and workflow platform provides additional high-bandwidth paths: malicious or compromised apps can receive Events API and interactivity payloads (webhook-style pushes) and use the Web API to pull history and files, then forward them to attacker-controlled web services (Exfiltration Over Webhook/Web Service). Workflow Builder allows non-developers to configure connectors that automatically post messages, file links, and form data from channels to external SaaS tools or HTTP endpoints, effectively creating low-code exfiltration pipelines. AI apps and agents, via assistant threads and streaming APIs, can forward concentrated conversation context to external LLM providers, with documented concern about data exfiltration risks.

Slack Connect introduces a cross-tenant replication vector (Transfer Data to Cloud Account): by sharing channels or DMs with an attacker-controlled Slack workspace, sensitive conversations and files are transparently copied into another Slack tenant, where the attacker can further export them. Finally, any compromised user account can exfiltrate data manually by searching for and copying content or downloading files via the UI, or semi-automatically by scripting Web API calls using user or bot tokens (Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol relative to the attacker’s primary C2). Environmental constraints like MFA, SSO-only auth, IP allowlisting, and strict app approvals primarily harden initial compromise and app installation, but once an attacker controls suitable user/admin accounts or tokens, the documented Slack capabilities support multiple realistic, high-impact exfiltration methods.

vectors.comments: Although the compute and financial impact primarily hits external services integrated with Slack, the orchestration and abuse surface is Slack’s automation and AI app platform. This fits MITRE Resource Hijacking when attackers use the victim’s SaaS-integrated compute and APIs for their own goals.
vectors.impact_achieved: External services connected to Slack (LLM providers, CRMs, ticketing systems, etc.) are driven to high utilization, burning through quotas or incurring substantial cost, while Slack’s own automation engine is tied up orchestrating attacker-driven workloads instead of legitimate business tasks.

vectors.comments: Slack’s documented capabilities in this analysis do not include any customer-accessible SMS sending APIs, OTP/SMS verification endpoints, or telephony messaging services akin to Twilio or AWS SNS. MFA and SSO are handled via external IdPs and are not exposed as Slack APIs that an attacker could spam. Without a Slack-provided SMS messaging surface or public OTP web forms that trigger SMS, classic SMS Pumping as defined by MITRE is not realistically achievable via Slack.
vectors.impact_achieved: Not achievable via documented Slack capabilities; Slack does not operate as an SMS delivery service for customers in the way required for SMS Pumping.

vectors.comments: The Slack capabilities described here do not expose first-class payment flows, bank accounts, or monetary transfer mechanisms to workspace users or apps. While Slack is frequently integrated with systems that do handle money (for example, CRMs, billing platforms) and could be used as a social-engineering channel to facilitate fraud, those behaviors fall under other tactics (phishing, social engineering) and impact external financial systems, not Slack itself. Within the documented Slack surfaces and APIs, there is no credible, direct way to initiate or divert monetary transfers that would constitute Financial Theft in the MITRE sense.
vectors.impact_achieved: Direct theft of monetary assets via Slack’s own capabilities is not realistically achievable given the documented feature set; any financial loss would instead arise indirectly through social engineering or abuse of external systems, which are outside this impact-focused analysis.

impact.summary: From a pure Impact perspective, a motivated attacker with control of Slack admin roles or powerful apps can cause severe damage without touching underlying infrastructure. The highest-risk vectors are (1) configuration-driven data destruction (aggressive retention plus legal-hold manipulation), (2) EKM key revocation that instantly renders encrypted content unreadable, (3) subtle but systemic manipulation of Slack-based records and AI-generated summaries, and (4) large-scale account access removal via Admin and SCIM APIs. In addition, Slack’s automation and AI platforms can be hijacked to flood channels/DMs (including Slack Connect) and to drive costly workloads on external services. Environmental constraints like MFA, SSO-only auth, IP allowlisting, and admin approval for apps primarily raise the bar for initial compromise; once high-privilege identities or apps are under attacker control, these constraints do little to prevent the above impact methods.
